364431.question: This organism has quite the history with uses described in Greek mythology, pagan rituals as well as being used in Christmas decorations. What is it?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
364431.explanation: Answer: Mistletoe (Viscum album) is a plant parasite with a broad host range . Most commonly found on apple it can also be found on lime (Tilia spp.) and poplar (Populus spp.). Widely used as a Christmas decoration, the use of mistletoe was recorded by Pliny the Elder who described the significance of mistletoe on oaks to Druids. The Tree Council along with the University of Oxford and Fera Science are looking for participants for a citizen science survey to determine how abundant mistletoe is, and where it grows. More information can be found here: Be a MistleGo! Pioneer  Help us find the UKs mistletoe this winter  The Tree Council

364655.question: Fungicides (and insecticides) are often described as systemic.  What does systemic mean?
options: Active against a wide range of microorganisms
Active against a wide range of fungi both basidiomycetes and ascomycetes
Cannot be washed off the plant once applied
Moves into the plant will relocate within the plant
Dont know and dont want to guess
364655.correct_answer: Moves into the plant will relocate within the plant
364655.explanation: The correct answer is: Moves into the plant will relocate within the plant. Systemic chemicals enter the plant and will be moved around to new areas.  They generally move up and seldom get into the roots.

364422.question: Diaporthe vaccinii is a fungal disease that threatens which sauce so essential to Christmas Day lunch?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364422.explanation: Answer: Cranberry sauce. Diaporthe vaccinii is indigenous to North America. It has entered other continents with imported planting material of Vaccinium but has not in general established there. For example, it was found in Romania in experimental plots of introduced American cultivars but did not establish.

364420.question: Holly foliage and berries is often used in Christmas decorations. One disease can cause a leaf blight and kill bark. What is this disease?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
364420.explanation: Answer: Phytophthora ilicis Phytophthora ilicis causes holly leaf blight and is found only affects Ilex species. This disease can cause defoliation; leaf blotches and kill bark. Where holly has been planted in hedges, defoliation can appear as arches where the defoliation is at its widest nearer the ground.

364424.question: True firs (Abies spp.) are commonly grown as Christmas trees. Unfortunately, there is a disease which can cause severe cankers, leading to crown dieback and can potentially lead to the death of the tree. The organism responsible for the damage produces small, rounded, red fruit bodies (perithecia). What is the disease?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
364424.explanation: Answer: Neonectria neomacrospora . A fungal disease which can cause severe dieback and eventual death of true firs. Originally recorded in North America, there were old records of its presence in Europe (outside Denmark and Norway), although not causing severe symptoms. Although known to be present in the UK, reports have increased since 2015. Tree deaths have often occurred on fir species in landscape plantings, Christmas tree plantations, and forest stands.

348210.question: This photo shows a spider catching a hoverfly.  Hoverflies are considered to be beneficial insects as they eat pests.  How should we view spiders?
options: They reduce the beneficial insect numbers and should be controlled
They are generally pests themselves and should be controlled
They are beneficial themselves as they prey upon pests
They have almost no effect on the pest status of a crop
I dont know and dont want to guess
348210.correct_answer: They are beneficial themselves as they prey upon pests
348210.explanation: The correct answer is: They are beneficial themselves as they prey upon pests. Spiders are very rarely pests and are generally seen as useful members of the crop fauna as they will predate pests. The incorrect answers were: They reduce the beneficial insect numbers and should be controlled. They can predate beneficial insects as seen in the photo, but this is unusual, and will generally consume pests. They are generally pests themselves and should be controlled. There are no examples of spiders as pests of crops (mites are related to spiders but are not spiders). They have almost no effect on the pest status of a crop. This is not true and they can reduce pest numbers considerably.

364656.question: When considering a fungicide container, what information does the trade name (the big name on the front) provide?
options: It provides no information whatsoever with regard the contents
The name can be helpful in learning about the resistance grouping
It will indicate how the product is formulated
It will provide information on what it can be used to control
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364656.correct_answer: It provides no information whatsoever with regard the contents
364656.explanation: The correct answer is: It provides no information whatsoever with regard the contents. The names of agrochemicals are invented by those marketing the product, It may be a corruption of the active ingredients but often is not.  It is a marketing name and it tells you nothing about the contents.

355779.question: This is a common ornamental (Codiaeum) used in hedges and other barriers. This is in Sri Lanka. My good friend Ari is smiling because Ive just told him what this is. He thought this was normal growth, but its not. What made him smile?
options: Varietal characteristic  this is a healthy plant
355779.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma . I was first alerted to this infection by my colleague Yaima Arocha. She spotted the strappy, thin leaves and contrasted them with the broader leaves (look bottom left) in Uganda. The plants tested positive for phytoplasma . Such symptoms are widespread in the tropics, though whether you consider this plant diseased is another matter. Comments on the other options: Yes, it could be a virus , but Id expect to see less vigorous growth and perhaps death of leaves. You could argue that this is a varietal characteristic: this is what people are used to seeing and the plant is growing vigorously. Poinsettias are infected by a phytoplasma and sold on their compact shape. Definitely not insect feeding. Ari was smiling because I saw an infected plant and he saw normal growth.

344544.question: Which of the following problems could not be responsible for the splitting of the petioles in this rhubarb?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
344544.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria Bacteria can cause leaves to collapse due to rotting, but the tissue in this image does not appear to be rotten or water soaked. It appears to be healthy apart from the areas that have split open. The incorrect answers were: Physiological problem This is what I think is causing the problem (although it is very strange as the plants either side are unaffected). Plants, usually fruits, can split open if they take up water too quickly. It may superficially look like insect damage or pathogen infection, but the wound is generally clean. Phytoplasma infection Phytoplasma infection can cause gross morphological changes to the development of a plant. There is no evidence that this symptom is due to a phytoplasma but this is the kind of symptom they can provoke. Animal damage It looks like a large animal has laid on the plant and snapped the leaf blade at the point of attachment to the petiole.  There is no sign of any infection at the site of breakage.

364425.question: Leaf spot on sprouts: what clues seen in the photo indicate that this infection is due a fungus:
options: Spreading from the side of the leaf Small black dots within the infected area Rings within the spot
Small black dots within the infected area Rings within the spot
Spreading from the side of the leaf Limited by the leaf vein
Spreading from the side of the leaf Small black dots within the infected area Rings within the spot  Limited by the leaf vein
364425.correct_answer: Small black dots within the infected area Rings within the spot
364425.explanation: Answer: Small black dots within the infected area. Rings within the spot ; the small black dots within the spot are fungal structures and the rings are common in fungal infections. Spreading from the edge of the leaf and limited by leaf veins are more generally associated with bacterial leafspots.

I Dont know and dont want to guess

357003.explanation: The correct answer is: Nothing: it is a healthy leaf: There are no symptoms to be seen; this ornamental plant has been selected to appear in this variegated form. However the speckling does look like mite damage.

355776.question: Bramble (if youre Scottish) or blackberry shoot (Rubus sp,), an unwelcome invader from my neighbours garden that I have tried to get rid of. Look carefully at the small clusters of leaves and compare with the normal leaves on the far left. Is this a biotic disease or could it be something else?
355776.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage. Look out for bunches of string-like leaves, as shown here. Glyphosate doesnt always work and although the blackberry canes have been  damaged, they continue to grow. Damn. Comments on the other options: Phytoplasmas can stimulate growth and have been recorded on Rubus spp. in the UK, though normally associated with stunting . Lack of nutrients will reduce growth, not stimulate it. Insect (or rather arthropod  mites usually) feeding can produce unusual growth, but not here.

options: Hyperparasitism of the powdery mildew pathogen
Dont know and dont want to guess
346541.correct_answer: Hyperparasitism of the powdery mildew pathogen
346541.explanation: The correct answer is: Hyperparasitism of the powdery mildew pathogen Ampelomyces quisqualis is a fungal pathogen of fungi. It is attacking the powdery mildew growing on the surface of the leaf. The incorrect answers were: Powdery mildew infection Yes, it is powdery mildew , but that is not what you can see. The powdery mildew has been over grown by the pathogen Algal growth This is the most convincing wrong answer and it could be algal growth, but it is not. Sooty mould Always black and generally not in discrete patches as seen here.

359222.question: What is the problem with the edge of these leaves?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359222.explanation: The correct answer is: Mineral deficiency: This is tip burn and is the lettuce equivalent of blossom end rot . In the same way as the tissue at the end of a tomato will break down, because the plant cannot mobilise calcium to the area fast enough, something similar is happening here. The edge of the leaf is growing so quickly it becomes short of calcium and the tissue dies.

I I dont know and dont want to guess

364429.question: Current season needle necrosis is a condition affecting Abies in Europe and North America and causes chlorotic spots or bands which later turn necrotic on new growth around 2-4 weeks after bud break. What causes the disease?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
364429.explanation: Answer: Sydowia polyspora The symptoms have been observed on noble fir ( Abies procera ), Nordmann fir ( A. nordmanniana ) and grand fir ( A. grandis ) on both continents. Under certain conditions, this fungus will function as a minor, weak foliar pathogen causing small foliar lesions. It is also associated with shoot and tip dieback and injury-related blue stain in several pine species.

340693.question: This symptom of tip die back on the lower leaves of maize is extremely common, it is symptom of a deficiency of which nutrient?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340693.explanation: The correct answer is: Nitrogen: A deficiency of the major nutrients (NPK) is always seen in the lower leaves first. This tip dieback of the leaf is characteristic of nitrogen deficiency in maize but not in other crops. The general yellowing of the lower leaves is a more general symptom . The incorrect answers were Potassium: in the case of potassium (K) shortage it is the outsides of the leaves that are the first to show symptoms. Sulphur: as sulphur is not a major nutrient, the symptoms are seen in the upper leaves first. The symptoms of sulphur deficiency is a general yellowing of the whole leaf. Phosphate: shortage of phosphate (P) induces a reddening of the lower regions of the plant.

342528.question: Irrigation systems which are poorly installed and maintained can lead to this white material appearing on the soil surface. What is the material?
options: Fungal mycelium growing due to the excessive moisture
Bleaching of the humus from the normal brown to white
Salts rising up from below and crystalizing on the soil surface
Fine root hairs searching for water on the very surface of the soil
Dont know and dont want to guess
342528.correct_answer: Salts rising up from below and crystalizing on the soil surface
342528.explanation: The correct answer is: Salts rising up from below and crystalizing on the soil surface. If an irrigation system provides all the water for a crop and the water has the slightest mineral content, salts will build up over time on the surface of the soil. When installing an irrigation system, it is often necessary to install drainage too so that the soil could be flushed through occasionally. The incorrect answers were: Fungal mycelium growing due to the excessive moisture ; this only occasionally happens in extremely humid conditions, not where an irrigation system is necessary. Bleaching of the humus from the normal brown to white ; even in the strongest sun, light does not bleach soil. Fine root hairs searching for water on the very surface of the soil ; root hairs extend only one millimetre from the root at most and will never grow to the surface.

366380.question: Pre-border  intelligence Q1 Under Plant Health legislation, a number of plant pests and diseases are classified as quarantine organisms and are therefore subject to statutory control. Inspectors are required to become familiar with the range of quarantine organisms and their known hosts through formal training and regular updates.  Select the information sites below that provide information on the UKs quarantine plant pests and diseases
options: The Plant Health Phytosanitary Conditions Amendment EU Exit Regulations 2020
European and Mediterranean Plant Protection Organization EPPO
Plant Pathology s new disease reports
366380.explanation: Correct answer : All of the above. We use a wide range of scientifically relevant sources, trade intelligence, feedback from our clients. Early identification is important to help combat quarantine pests and diseases. If you find a quarantine organism or suspect one may be present, you should contact your local PHSI immediately to alert them. In England and Wales: To report suspicion of a quarantine plant pest or disease , or for other plant health queries not specified above, telephone 0300 1000 313 or email planthealth.info@apha.gov.uk

359228.question: What has caused the distortion to this lettuce?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359228.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus : This is a disease called lettuce big vein. The virus is spread by zoospores of a fungus ( Olpidium virulentus) released from sporangia that live in the soil and infect lettuce roots. The virus also enters resting spores, allowing it to survive for years in soil, in the absence of a growing host plant .

355783.question: What is the cause of these symptoms on Peach trees?
355783.explanation: The correct answer is: Yes, its another phytoplasma , this time peach yellows . Widespread in Europe with variable yet common symptoms: distorted leaf development, distinct yellowing and dieback Comments on the other options: Birds eat leaves; they dont alter growth. The symptoms do look virusy and this is a reasonable guess given that the photograph is taken from a distance (in Cyprus). Prolonged lack of water would result in a general decline and loss of leaves all over.

357682.question: Soyabean growth was uneven, yet there were no obvious disease symptoms. These growths were found on the roots. What are they?
357682.explanation: The correct answer is: Nitrogen-fixing nodules. Note their uniformity. Comments: Nematode galls are more irregular in form, size and distribution. Uneven growth above ground could be the result of many things e.g.  lack of water unequal fertilizer application, soil structure.

356593.question: What are the symptoms of potassium deficiency?
options: Marginal necrosis edges of the leaves going brown in the upper leaves
Marginal necrosis edges of the leaves going brown in the lower leaves
Dont know and dont want to guess
356593.correct_answer: Marginal necrosis edges of the leaves going brown in the lower leaves
356593.explanation: The correct answer is: Marginal necrosis (edges of the leaves going brown) in the lower leaves: Can be confused with wind damage or bacterial infection but the symptoms are always seen in the lower leaves first. The incorrect answers were: Reddening and stunting : you were probably getting confused with phosphate deficiency which has these symptoms. Yellowing: you were probably getting confused with nitrogen deficiency which has these symptoms. Marginal necrosis (edges of the leaves going brown) in the upper leaves; a deficiency of all the major nutrients (NPK) are seen in the lower leaves first.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355513.question: Leafspots; all quite small and all the same size.  What does this indicate is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
355513.explanation: The correct answer is: Insects: These symptoms are not proof that insects are responsible, but strongly suggest they are the cause. Many sucking pests leave no marks at all, but others such as leafhoppers and planthoppers cause this symptom . The incorrect answers were: Bacteria ; bacterial leaf spots are often associated with the leaf edge or damage and are water-soaked and of variable sizes. Fungi ; fungal leaf spots are usually larger than this and are not quite so uniform in their appearance. Viruses ; this would be a very unusual symptom for a virus .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

354529.question: Willow growing near to the Thames in SW London. What might have caused these yellow-green clusters of small leaves to develop?
354529.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma  maybe. Similar symptoms have been associated with witches brooms on Salix spp. in Central Asia, Iran. Ive seen this in Ukraine and Poland and I expect it to be more widespread yet under-recorded. Comments on the other options: Theres no diagnostic evidence to link this with phytoplasma in the UK, yet theres a clear similarity to symptoms widespread on willows elsewhere. Its too distinctive and extensive to be a genetic abnormability, an otherwise attractive option for unusual growths. But also consider what insect feeding (not here, in my opinion) and bacterial infections can induce (see ash example earlier). Waterlogging? Nuh!

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

342531.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: All plant viruses can be transmitted by insects
All plant feeding insects can transmit viruses
Most viruses have a specific relationship with their vectors
Laboratory work with micro manipulators can mimic the transmission of viruses
I dont know and I dont want to guess
342531.correct_answer: Most viruses have a specific relationship with their vectors
342531.explanation: The correct answer is: Most viruses have a specific relationship with their vectors: the relationship between the vector and the virus is complex and incompletely understood. This relationship is often very specific. The incorrect answers were: All plant viruses can be transmitted by insects; not true, although many viruses are transmitted by insects, other vectors include fungi, nematodes, seed or mechanical means. All plant feeding insects can transmit viruses; not true, some groups are very commonly seen as virus vectors (such as aphids) and many cannot transmit viruses at all. Laboratory work with micro manipulators can mimic the transmission of all insect transmitted viruses; there is a great deal more to the transmission of viruses than simple mechanical contamination of the mouthparts and micro manipulators cannot replicate this.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352377.question: When considering foliar fungicide application with a knapsack sprayer, which of these will affect the amount of liquid spray applied per acre when spraying to run off?
options: The concentration of the mix in the tank
The walking speed of the operator
Dont know and dont want to guess
352377.correct_answer: The walking speed of the operator
352377.explanation: The correct answer is: The walking speed of the operator: The speed at which the operator walks through the crop will affect the volume of diluted spray applied to an area of land. The incorrect answers were: The concentration of the mix in the tank ; this will not affect the amount of diluted liquid exiting the nozzle. The size of the crop; the spray operator would have to slow down for a larger crop if it was to be fully coated, but the size of the crop will not affect the amount of spray required.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

348209.question: These bumps are a symptom called oedema.  What is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
348209.explanation: The correct answer is: Physiological problem The cause of oedema is still a mystery.  There is no pathogen or pest involved and it is entirely physiological.  The uptake of water seems to be the issue. The incorrect answers were: Insect feeding Sap feeding insects do not often cause feeding marks, but when they do, they are often necrotic. Fungal infection Rust fungi can sometimes cause a slight blister before they burst the surface, but they would never get this large, nor so uniform. Mineral deficiency There are occasional unusual symptoms caused by a lack of nutrients (blossom end rot is a good example) but this is not one of them.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360478.question: What is this pest attacking this rose bud?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360478.explanation: The correct answer is: Aphids: A very common pest characterised by: the pear-shaped soft body, obvious legs and, normally, a lack of wings on most of the population.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365345.question: Tip dieback can have many causes such as ageing and mechanical damage due to wind, but this is not the case here.  What has caused the tips of these rice leaves to wither and die?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365345.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode infection: This is one of the few cases where nematodes attack above ground. The rice white tip nematode (Aphelenchoides besseyi) is the exception and lives in the tips of rice leaves where the feeding causes these symptoms.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362994.question: Unknown plant (yes, also at RHS Wisley)
362994.explanation: The correct answer is: Confused Comments: Im puzzled by this flowering plant (whose label could not be found). What is the significance of the clear boundary between the yellowed leaves and the healthy ones in the background? Uneven application of fertiliser? It doesnt look like a virus  note the even development of the yellowing. Or is it varietal? So confused is my best suggestion.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352203.question: What is the best term to describe this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352203.explanation: The correct answer is: Yellowing: It is sometimes called  Chlorosis , but yellowing is generally a good description of the symptom when the plant has no other symptoms than looking paler than a healthy plant. The incorrect answers were: Pale: the plant could be considered as pale, but this is not a word often used to describe plant symptoms. Necrotic: this term is used to describe tissue that has turned brown and is dead. Nitrogen deficient: this may be the cause of the symptom , but it is not the name of the symptom .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

361082.question: Chitting is a process whereby the potatoes are grown in trays initially. What does this achieve?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
361082.explanation: The correct answer is: An earlier crop. The main reason people will chit the potatoes is so that they are off to a flying start when they are planted.  Commercial growers are often unable to do this as the mechanical planters will knock off the developing roots and shoots.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352365.question: This is a high magnification photo of a spore but of which pathogen?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
352365.explanation: The correct answer is: Septoria apicola : You are probably not familiar with the spores of Septoria, but none of the other pathogens produces spores so it has to be the fungal pathogen . The incorrect answers were: Cucumber mosaic virus ; viruses have no resting structures such as spores and almost all of them (TMV is a major exception) have no survival outside a host or vector . Erwinia amylovora ; a very common bacterial pathogen , bacterial plant pathogens do not produce spores. Xanthomonas campestris ; see above.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

358234.question: What are these structures on this root?
options: There is no microbial involvement these are adventitious roots
I dont know and I dont want to guess
358234.explanation: The correct answer is: Nitrogen fixing nodules These growths are pink and displaced to the side of the root, these two characteristics make a diagnosis simple.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364660.question: Once a fungal pathogen population has become resistant to an active ingredient, to what extent will this spread to other fungi?
options: Once resistance has occurred most fungal species of the region will quickly become resistant
Resistance will not spread to other fungal species
Plasmids are readily exchanged between fungi carrying resistance genes
A resistant fungal population is unlikely to survive and will die out
Dont know and dont want to guess
364660.correct_answer: Resistance will not spread to other fungal species
364660.explanation: The correct answer is: Resistance will not spread to other fungal species. Unlike bacterial species which readily share resistance genes the same is not the case for fungi. A single fungal species may have become resistant to a chemical but that has little bearing on other fungi (other than you have created conditions for resistance to occur).

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362992.question: Basil growing at RHS Wisley
362992.explanation: The correct answer is: Healthy Comments: A quote from the Superman films seems apt, adapted for plants: Is it a Virus ? Is it a phytoplasma ? Or is it simply another varietal characteristic? The label at Wisley said Lettuce leaved Basil, indicating that this is a named variety. It could still, of course, be related to a virus infection, albeit of the harmless and valued sort.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352368.question: Repackaging of pesticides is generally a bad idea as, often, the information on the label is not carried over to both packages.  Despite this, farmers will frequently split packs for various reasons. When doing so, how should they be advised?
options: Use plastic fizzy drinks bottles as they are tough and will withstand pressure
Use containers that cannot be sealed incase pressure builds up inside the container
Use metal food containers as they are the strongest
Use another pesticide container of a different type
I dont know and I dont want to guess
352368.correct_answer: Use another pesticide container of a different type
352368.explanation: The correct answer is: Use another pesticide container of a different type: This is not good practice, but if a farmer is to split a pack, at least get them to use a pesticide container. That way, if there is a mix up, the worst that can happen is that the wrong chemical is sprayed onto a crop. The incorrect answers were: Use plastic fizzy drinks bottles as they are tough and will withstand pressure; this is very common behaviour in some regions but is the worst choice. It can easily lead to accidental death when the pesticide is drunk by a third party. Use containers that cannot be sealed in-case pressure builds up inside the container; any container containing a pesticide should be sealed. Use metal food containers as they are the strongest; the strength of the container can be an issue but, most importantly, it should NOT be an old food container.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360092.question: What are the lumps on the side of these potato roots?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
360092.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode cysts These are the dead bodies of the female nematodes that are packed with nematode eggs.  Unlike galls, which often develop as part of the root, the cysts are very much attached to the root rather than part of it.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364662.question: The mode of action of a fungicide is determined by which aspect of a product?
options: Range of crops is it suitable for
The active ingredient of the product
The range of fungi that it is active against
Dont know and dont want to guess
364662.correct_answer: The active ingredient of the product
364662.explanation: The correct answer is: The active ingredient of the product: The mode of action (how the chemical kills the fungus) is due to the active ingredient(s).  The remainder of the canister is important but are unrelated to mode of action.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

358228.question: What pest is attacking this carrot root?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
358228.explanation: The correct answer is: Aphids It is unusual for aphids to attack underground but, as you can see, it does happen.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350677.question: These two photos are of rust on wheat.  What is the relationship between the two photos?
options: They are the same fungus and the environment has caused the difference in colour
They are the same fungus but producing different spore types
The same fungus but darker spores are older
I dont know and I dont want to guess
350677.explanation: The correct answer is: Unrelated; two different rust fungi: The photo on the left is brown rust and that on the right yellow rust. The incorrect answers were: They are the same fungus and the environment has caused the difference in colour: the environment does not cause a great deal of colour change in rust spores. They are the same fungus but producing different spore types: rust fungi do produced different kind of spore within the same pustule but these are almost always black. The same fungus but darker spores are older: rust spores dont darken with age.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340694.question: All of the options are known to cause this symptom except one. Can you identify which one it is?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340694.explanation: The correct answer is: Mites: Mites are a very common pest on many crops especially those grown under cover, however, despite the many and severe symptoms they can induce, they never cause plants to wilt . It is not clear why mites are more of a problem in a protected cropping environment but it may be due to not being rained upon. The incorrect answers were: Nematodes: cause considerable damage to the roots of plants attack and commonly cause wilts Bacteria: it is common for stem infecting bacteria to cause wilts. Insects: both stem borers and root dwelling insects commonly cause wilts by attacking the stem or roots.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357684.question: Growth of Okra plants was uneven and sometimes stunted, as seen in South Africa. Below ground the root was swollen, as shown in the photo. The root has been cut lengthways to reveal internal symptoms. What is the cause?
357684.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode feeding Comments : Swollen shoots with knobbly, uneven surfaces usually suggest one of two things: nematode attack or clubroot. Clubroot only occurs in Brassicas.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365625.question: Traditionally potatoes are ridged up (or earthed up) which means that the soil is raised near the developing plant.   Why is this done?
options: It prevents spores of late blight dripping onto the tubers
It prevents light from turning the potatoes green
It allows the soil to warm up quickly
All of the above answers are correct
I dont know and I dont want to guess
365625.correct_answer: All of the above answers are correct
365625.explanation: The correct answer is: All of the answers are correct. It prevents spores of late blight dripping onto the tubers and prevents light from turning the potatoes green, it extends the stems from which the potatoes develop, and it also protects from frost and allows the soil to warm up quickly.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340697.question: What is the cause of these galls on this mango leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340697.explanation: The correct answer is: Insect galls: This is the larval stage of the mango gall midge. Larvae penetrate plant tissues and live in flattened, blister-like galls. Final-instar larvae emerge from damaged tissues and fall to the soil where they pupate. When conditions are favourable a new generation of adults emerges within 4-6 days, but when conditions are unfavourable the full-grown larvae construct silk cocoons in which they rest for one or more years before emerging. The incorrect answers were: Frass: this would be very unusual frass. The frass from caterpillars is large and black like this but is never stuck to (or embedded into) leaf tissue . Thrips frass can be stuck to the leaves like this but is never this large. Bacterial galls: it is unusual to see bacterial galls on a leaf but the three things which indicate that these are not bacterial galls is the fact that there is so many of them, they are all approximately the same size and that they are smooth. Anthracnose : this is a fungal disease that causes extensive leaf spots and death of the leaves and not the small smooth disc-shaped galls we see here .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357685.question: Above ground, this common bean plant shows poor growth. This is what I found when I examined the roots. Look closely at the photo for the likely cause.
357685.explanation: The correct answer is: Bean-root aphid ( Trifidaphus phaseoli ) Comments on the other options: Look closely and you can see the aphids feeding on the roots. At first I thought this was waterlogging, but digging up the plants clearly revealed the real cause.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362988.question: Celery leaves from the RHS Gardens Wisley
362988.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Im assuming this is a virus , possibly celery mosaic virus . The symptoms are quite mild but there is a characteristic yellow patchiness to the leaves, coupled with some distortion and twisting.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

351963.question: What can the development of a disease within a crop stand tell you about the pathogen involved?
options: How long it can remain dormant in the field
Whether it is a biotroph or a necrotroph
The means by which it is spread
Which type of pathogen group it is
I dont know and dont want to guess
351963.correct_answer: The means by which it is spread
351963.explanation: The correct answer is: The means by which it is spread: The means by which the pathogen moves from one plant to another can be determined (to some extent) by the development of the disease as it spreads through the crop (detailed diagnosis would still be required to determine what the pathogen is). The incorrect answers were: How long it can remain dormant in the field ; it would be very difficult to determine this based on the pathogen spread as, once the infection is established in the field, the dormancy is no longer an issue. Whether it is biotroph or a necrotroph; these are descriptions of how the pathogen interacts with the host and not the way in which it spreads. Which type of pathogen group it is; there are many different pathogen groups and many of them spread in many different ways, it is not possible to infer the type of pathogen from its spread.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350678.question: This brassica seedling is showing the symptoms of a deficiency in a nutrient. Which nutrient would appear to be lacking?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
350678.explanation: The correct answer is: Phosphate: Stunted growth and reddening of the leaves (especially the lower leaves) is a classic sign of phosphate deficiency. The incorrect answers were: Nitrogen: yellowing of the lower leaves is typical of nitrogen deficiency. Potassium : leaf edge scorch of the lower leaves is typical of potassium (K) deficiency. Molybdenum: deficiency in molybdenum is not often seen except in brassicas. The symptoms are reduced laminar and cupping of the laminar in the upper leaves.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365347.question: Extremely unusual symptoms for this organism.  What has caused this dark staining in this radish?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365347.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew infection. This is the only case I know of where a downy mildew attack below ground.  The dark staining (it is not a rot ) is extremely characteristic; once you know.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

356596.question: The surface growth and distortion seen here, on these lychee leaves, is caused by the lychee rust mite.  What problem is the growth more typical of?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356596.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew . The soft velvety growth on the underside of the leaves could easily be mistaken for a downy mildew (although not usually as dark as this).  The mite (which is too small to be seen) has induced the soft growth on the underside of the leaf; the brown hairs are actually leaf material.  In the field, it is easy to tell the difference as the downy mildew sporulation is easy to wipe off and this is not the case with the downy growth seen here. The incorrect answers were: Powdery mildew : powdery mildews are always white and almost always on the upper leaf surface. Nematode attack; is never associated with growth on leaves. Glasshouse red spider mites: produce a lot of webbing but it never coats the leaves like this.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

359224.question: What is causing this rot on at the base of this lettuce?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
359224.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria There are some clues to suggest that this is due to a bacterial pathogen .  The water soaking symptoms that arespreading up the leaf veins and the total collapse of the tissue all indicate a bacterial pathogen . Waterlogging may have led to the pathogen infection, but it could not be considered the cause. Compare this with the Sclerotinia infection of question 1. This is Pseudomonas cichorii infection.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

356601.question: What is the material growing on these leaves?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356601.explanation: The correct answer is: Algae: Growth of algae on leaves can be common on perennial crops, especially on the lower (shaded) leaves.  There are very few algae that damage plants (as pathogens). The incorrect answers were: Powdery mildew ; are always white. Sooty mould; is always black. Downy mildew ; is generally pink, purple, violet or white on the underside of the leaf.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

359226.question: What is causing this rot in the heart of this lettuce?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
359226.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection: The sporulation of the fungus (Botrytis) is clearly visible on the surface of this heavily infected lettuce. Nematodes rarely attack above ground and bacteria never produce structures large enough to see unaided.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

356997.question: This is the poster boy of exceptions to the rules of plant pathology.  This is peach leaf curl caused by Taphrina deformans, a fungal pathogen but what are the symptoms more typical of?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356997.explanation: The correct answer is: Mite damage: Mites can cause gross deformities within a leaf such as that seen here. None of the other problems would ever cause a symptom such as this.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365348.question: As for the previous question dark staining in underground storage organs. What is the cause this time?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
365348.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection. What appear to be tight constrictions around the tubers and the internal browning are very common in some parts of Africa and are due to infection by Cassava brown streak virus .   The foliar symptoms are mild but the tubers are severely affected.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360091.question: What is this structure (marked Cl) within an epidermal cell of a plant infected with Tobacco mosaic virus?
options: Debris on the surface of the leaf
I dont know and I dont want to guess
360091.explanation: The correct answer is: Crystals of the virus : Although it is often said (said by me) that viruses are far too small to be seen, even with a high power light microscope, this is a crystal of TMV. Tobacco mosaic virus is the only virus that reaches such high levels in the host that it actually crystalizes and, with careful microscopy, these crystals can sometimes be seen in the epidermal cells of infected plants.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350672.question: Natural enemies is a common phrase; insects which may reduce the population of a pest but what about diseases on weeds?  How should we treat disease infected weeds?
options: Remove all weeds as they will impact on yield
Leave the infected weeds so that the disease could spread
The removal of the weed depends on the potential for the disease to spread to the crop
Leave all the weeds so that the disease can spread to healthy weeds
Dont know and dont want to guess
350672.correct_answer: Remove all weeds as they will impact on yield
350672.explanation: The correct answer is: Remove all weeds as they will impact on yield. It is extremely unlikely (but not unknown) that a pathogen would reduce the impact of a weed population in an agricultural setting. You are better off to remove all weeds. NB. Pathogens are used very successfully in classical biological control . The incorrect answers were: Leave the infected weeds so that the disease could spread : the disease may spread from the infected weeds to uninfected weeds but the competition from the original weeds would be too great to justify this plan. The removal of the weed depends on the potential for the disease to spread to the crop: some diseases can spread from weeds to crops but see the answer above. Leave all the weeds so that the disease can spread to healthy weeds: it would be foolhardy to leave all the weeds thinking that the pathogen would take care of them.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

366394.question: Border  inspections Q1 International Standards for Phytosanitary Measures (ISPMs) are standards aiming to harmonise phytosanitary measures for the purpose of facilitating international trade.  One of these, ISPM 12, is the use of Phytosanitary Certificates, which are official documents attesting that a consignment meets import requirements Which of the following should not be included on a valid phytosanitary certificate?
options: Additional declaration statement providing specific additional information on a consignment in relation to regulated pests or regulated articles
Quantities and genera of plants being moved
Period of validity within 14 days of issue
I dont know and dont want to guess
366394.explanation: Correct answer : Value of plants should not be included. Link to ISPMs: https://www.ippc.int/en/core-activities/standards-setting/ispms/ More info on UK Phytosanitary Certificates: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/65859ac823b70a000d234e7f/Defra_Phytosanitary-Certificates-Leaflet.pdf

364427.question: What disease is this potato tuber suffering from?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364427.explanation: Answer: Potato blight . Affected tubers have a reddish-brown decay below the skin, firm at first but often soon developing into a soft rot as the blighted tissues are subsequently invaded by bacteria. Light attacks of blight may not be visible on the tubers, but many infected tubers will rot in store.

348217.question: When applying a foliar fungicide as a spray, the amount of active chemical ingredient per area is important, but what about the amount of water that carries it?
options: The dilution of the chemical is unimportant provided the correct amount of active ingredient is applied
The dilution of the chemical has to be very exact to ensure best results
The dilution can be varied within certain parameters
The more concentrated the solution the better and dilution is done only to make the concentrate go further
I dont know and dont want to guess
348217.correct_answer: The dilution can be varied within certain parameters
348217.explanation: The correct answer is: The dilution can be varied within certain parameters. The correct amount of active ingredient should be applied to the correct location on the crop and, within certain limits, the amount of water  as a carrier fluid  can be varied. The incorrect answers were: The dilution of the chemical is unimportant provided the correct amount of active ingredient is applied. This is true to a point, but once the spray becomes too dilute, the spray will run off leaves and onto the soil. The dilution of the chemical has to be very exact to ensure best results. The dilution of chemical does not always have to be exact and, usually, there is some sort of flexibility in the range of dilutions possible. The more concentrated the solution the better and dilution is done only to make the concentrate go further. A more concentrated fungicide will generally have greater capacity to kill the fungus, but it would be un-economic, illegal and would scorch the crop.

348208.question: What is causing these pale spots on this bean leaf?
options: Viral infection a local lesion host
Dont know and dont want to guess
348208.explanation: The correct answer is: Rust fungus The brown rusty coloured pustules are clearly visible in the more advanced stages. The small pale dots are also infection sites but the pathogen has not yet broken through the leaf epidermis (the tough layer of cells that creates the leaf surface). The incorrect answers were: Sucking insect probing Many sucking pests, aphids, mealybugs, scale etc., do not create any damage at the site of penetration . Some pests do leave marks, but often they are necrotic and not pale like this. Viral infection; a local lesion host A local lesion host is a concept familiar to many who have worked with viruses but it is not often seen in the field.  The rust pustules give away the real cause. Herbicide spray damage Symptoms can appear spattered across the leaf like this, but normally those that create an extremely localised response (e.g., paraquat) produce necrotic spots, not pale ones such as these.

360093.question: What is this on the underside of this chilli leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
360093.explanation: The correct answer is: Powdery mildew : It is unusual to see powdery mildew sporulating on the underside of a leaf, but it does happen as can be seen here.

350676.question: What is the cause of this unusual yellowing pattern on these leaves? .
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
350676.correct_answer: I dont know and I dont want to guess
350676.explanation: The correct answer is: I dont know and I dont want to guess: I appreciate that this is a bit of a cop out from me, but if anyone has any suggestion as to the cause of this extremely unusual symptom I would be glad to hear it. The other answers were: High temperature and dry weather : not symptoms associated with these conditions. Mineral deficiency : there is no mineral deficiency that gives these symptoms. Viral infection : possible as viruses can create very unusual symptoms but it is far from typical in every regard. Herbicide damage : possible but the other leaves on the plant were unaffected.

346538.question: Look carefully at the photo. The tops of these potato plants have turned yellow and one plant is wilting. What is the most likely cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
346538.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage The clue here is to look at the weeds near the edge of the vegetable patch .  The gardener was clearly spraying off the weeds at the edge of the bed and has just caught the potato plants with the spray. This low dose of glyphosate has produced symptoms at the top of the plant. The young leaves are turning yellow, spreading up from the base of the leaf, but notice that the distal ends of these leaves remain green; these symptoms are typical of sub-lethal glyphosate exposure. The incorrect answers were: Iron deficiency The yellowing of younger leaves is typical of iron deficiency, but, characteristically, if iron shortage is the cause, the leaf veins remain green. Iron deficiency does not induce a wilt . Phytoplasma infection Yellowing is a common symptom of phytoplasma infection, but they very rarely cause wilts. Fungal infection In the absence of yellowing grass and weeds nearby, this would be a sensible suggestion, although other factors could have caused these symptoms.

363379.question: What could have caused this wilt without yellowing or leaf death?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363379.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial infection: Ralstonia solanacearum is a bacterial pathogen that frequently causes a rapid wilt .  The wilt is generally the first sign of disease , the plants will survive for several days (recovering from the wilt at night) before finally turning yellow and necrotic.

options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357324.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew , Peronospora farinose , is sporulating profusely on the underside of these fat hen leaves. Note that there is almost no host reaction to the pathogen .

357983.question: How many pathogens are causing this symptom on apple?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357983.explanation: The correct answer is: There is no pathogen involved Didnt mean to trick you, but this is not peach leaf curl (that is not a problem on apple).  It is an insect pest , the rosy apple aphid, that is causing these dramatic symptoms.

342534.question: What effect do medically important antibiotics have on bacterial plant pathogens?
options: They have no effect on bacterial pathogens that affect plants
They provide good control of bacterial pathogens
They will not control bacterial plant pathogens but do control viruses
They will remove the natural biological control on leaves and will actually make the situation worse
Dont know and dont want to guess
342534.correct_answer: They provide good control of bacterial pathogens
342534.explanation: The correct answer is: They provide good control of bacterial pathogens: Streptomycin, Tetracycline and other medically important antibiotics are effective in controlling bacterial plant diseases but their use is prohibited in many countries due to fears that the resistance developing in the environment could spread to human and animal pathogens. The incorrect answers were: They have no effect on bacterial pathogens that affect plants : medically important antibiotics are very effective in controlling bacterial plant pathogens but should not be used . They will not control bacterial plant pathogens but do control viruses : this is not true -there are no known chemicals that will control viruses once within a plant. They will remove the natural biological control on leaves and will actually make the situation worse : the antibiotic application will reduce the natural bacterial populations but if the disease is present, it will have greater effect on the pathogen population.

349788.question: This symptom seen on these cherry leaves is interveinal chlorosis i.e. the zones between the leaf veins have turned yellow.  It is often a characteristic sign of a deficiency in which nutrient?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
349788.explanation: The correct answer is: Iron: Interveinal chlorosis in the upper leaves is a common symptom of iron deficiency. The incorrect answers were: Nitrogen: a yellowing (including the leaf veins) of the lower leaves can be the result of nitrogen deficiency. Phosphate: stunted plants, which are dark green with a slight red tinge, are symptoms associated with phosphate deficiency. Boron: the tip of the plant suffers necrosis and tiny leaves are produced when there is a boron deficiency.

355784.question: Leaf curl in field-grown tomatoes. What is happening?
355784.explanation: The correct answer is: Wind damage. There are probably other factors which contribute to a temporary response to localised water loss. Ive often seen it early in the morning, disappearing later in the day. Comments on the other options: Mite feeding causes leaf browning and the plant becomes ragged. Both viruses affect the lamina of the leaf, with changes in colour and reduced growth. When leaf curling affects an otherwise an unmarked leaf then start to suspect a non- pest cause. Check if leaves have been affected at the same time (as seen here), suggesting a sudden change and upset to growth, such as frost or herbicide damage. Diseases develop progressively.

360476.question: What has happened to this rose leaf?
options: Fungal infection spreading out across the leaf
Bacterial infection spreading out across the leaf
Fungal infection that has been overrun by bacterial infection
Bacterial infection that has been overrun by fungal infection
Dont know and dont want to guess
360476.correct_answer: Fungal infection that has been overrun by bacterial infection
360476.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection that has been overrun by bacterial infection. The black circular regions are infection by the fungal pathogen Diplocarpon rosea which causes Black spot of roses. What appears to have happened is that a bacterial pathogen has entered from the tip of the leaf and has overrun two of the three black spot infection sites.

361089.question: This symptom is known as spraing but what is the cause?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
361089.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus . Two viruses can cause this symptom of crescents/rings of necrosis within the tubers. Tobacco Rattle virus and Potato mop top can cause this symptom .

357327.question: What is this coating the upper leaves of this citrus tree?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357327.explanation: The correct answer is: Sooty mould. The sooty mould fungi are growing in the honey dew deposited by sucking insects on the upper branches.

options: Dont know and dont want to guess

366406.question: Post-border  surveillance Q3 An Inspector is asked to visit a member of the public on a sunny Friday morning. They have found two large live larvae on a palm in their garden. They have put them in a plastic tub with some airholes and cabbage leaves. The inspector collects the larvae and sends them to an independent laboratory for formal identification. For the most accurate identification the larvae should arrive promptly, undamaged, and alive. Which three are correct procedure when sending these larvae to the lab?
options: Send by Express post when you return to the office in the afternoon
Send to the labs in the tub with the leaves and air holes provided
Use a clear plastic tube so the diagnosticians can view the contents before opening it
Keep them in the fridge over the weekend then send it nextday delivery
Leave in the sun on the seat of your car while you carry on your inspections Palms are tropical after all so the sample will be fine there
Ensure they are packed with sufficient host material with slightly moistened soft paper to secure against movement and damage
366406.correct_answer: Ensure they are packed with sufficient host material with slightly moistened soft paper to secure against movement and damage
366406.explanation: Correct answers : Use a clear plastic tube, so the diagnosticians can view the contents before opening it. Keep them in the fridge over the weekend, then send it next-day delivery Ensure they are packed with sufficient host material with slightly moistened soft paper to secure against movement and damage. For an unknown pest it is important for the diagnostician to be able to see the pest before opening the container, particularly if it is alive and active. The larvae will be in better condition if they are kept alive in the fridge over the weekend, rather than being left in a post room at the lab. Pests should also be packaged to protect them from damage while in transit, to protect their identifying features and be grown on, if they are still alive. For further information on the Red Palm Weevil ( Rhynchophorus ferrugineus ): https://planthealthportal.defra.gov.uk/assets/factsheets/Rhynchophorus-ferrugineus-Defra-PP-Factsheet-Oct-2016-FINAL4.pdf Sample packaging information: https://www.fera.co.uk/crop-health/sample-shipping-information

363138.question: The blue ringed areas on this leaf are downy mildew of grapevine.  The red ringed regions appear similar but are a different problem.  What is that problem?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
363138.explanation: The correct answer is: The white surface growth of downy mildew can look similar to the eriophyid mite symptoms: This can be confusing in the field, however the downy mildew can easily be removed from the leaf whereas the growth associated with the mites cannot be removed.

357000.question: These are the symptoms of  Maize lethal necrosis disease caused by two viruses.  The symptoms are very atypical of viral infection what would more typically produce these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357000.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal disease : Without prior knowledge and based on the photo alone it would be reasonable to suggest that the problem was a fungal (or bacterial) pathogen . Nematodes could cause the general dieback but look at the healthy regions on the lower leaves, this does not look like a general decline.  Herbicides can cause similar symptoms but nearby plants are unaffected. A nutrient deficiency could not have caused this as the plant is too large to suddenly suffer from such severe symptoms.

363756.question: The lesions on these bean leaves are due to Peronospora viciae in many regards it is a typical downy mildew.  To what extent can the downy mildews be grown in culture?
options: It is not possible to grow any downy mildews in culture
All downy mildews will grow in culture on regular fungal media
Specialist media is required but they can be cultured
Some but not all downy mildews can be grown in culture
Dont know and dont want to guess
363756.correct_answer: It is not possible to grow any downy mildews in culture
363756.explanation: The correct answer is: It is not possible to grow any downy mildews in culture. They have to be maintained as resting spores or actively growing on a susceptible host.

352376.question: What can be done to prevent the spread of a virus within a single plant?
options: Antiviral sprays work well and should be applied as soon as symptoms are seen
Cut off the regions showing symptoms to prevent the spread to healthy areas
Insecticide sprays will prevent insects from transferring the virus to new areas of the same plant
There is nothing that can be done to prevent the spread of a virus within a plant
I dont know and I dont want to guess
352376.correct_answer: There is nothing that can be done to prevent the spread of a virus within a plant
352376.explanation: The correct answer is: There is nothing that can be done to prevent the spread of a virus within a plant: There are no chemicals that will prevent the spread within a plant and there are many areas that are symptomless but still carry the virus . The incorrect answers were: Antiviral sprays work well and should be applied as soon as symptoms are seen; they do not work. Cut off the regions showing symptoms to prevent the spread to healthy areas; there will be areas of the plant infected but not showing symptoms. Insecticide sprays will prevent insects from transferring the virus to new areas of the same plant; repeated infection from outside is not necessary for a virus to spread within a plant.

355512.question: Most caterpillars have 4 pairs of false legs on their body, this caterpillar has only 2 pairs (arrowed), what will this caterpillar turn into?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
355512.explanation: The correct answer is: Moth Many caterpillars have four pairs, but some have fewer, as seen here. It is not difficult to identify these caterpillars as loopers, based on the way they arch their body as they move. The incorrect answers were: Sawfly; sawfly larvae are often mistaken for caterpillars but, rather than having the typical 4 pairs of false legs or fewer, they have more than four pairs. Beetle; beetle larvae (grubs) dont have false legs like this, but they do have thoracic legs. Fly ; fly larvae (maggots) have no false legs, and no thoracic legs either.

349780.question: The symptoms in this photo are due to a fungal disease; citrus scab.   The leaf distortion seen here is an unusual symptom of fungal infection and is more often associated with which group of pathogens or problem?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
349780.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection: Mosaic (not seen here) and leaf distortion are both classic symptoms of infection by a virus . This is an example of leaf distortion NOT due to viral infection. The incorrect answers were: Bacteria: distortion of leaves is not associated with bacterial infection. Nutrient deficiencies: there are few examples of nutrient deficiencies causing distortion in leaves but this is extremely unusual. Water moulds: very occasionally, downy mildews can systemically infect the host, which then produces small, thick (distorted) leaves, but this is rare.

365343.question: Viral infection commonly induce leaf distortion but that is not the case here,  what has caused the distortion in this grapevine leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365343.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage. The herbicide 24 D is an auxin mimic and causes distortion as the plant develops. This grapevine leaf is barely recognisable due to its distortion.

362035.question: Pot-grown tomato declines and dies in a couple of weeks.
362035.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Late blight on tomatoes. Note the blackened stems as well as the dead leaves. Tomatoes are hardy plants, even when grown in pots, and many varieties sold in the UK are said to be  blight resistant. But when its wet and cold Phytophthora is always around to infect .

362033.question: Badly distorted peach leaves. What is the general category or type of cause?
362033.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Peach leaf curl is a common and dramatic disease with spectacular symptoms. Caused by Taphrina deformans . There are several other species which I was less aware of until I consulted Paul Hollidays excellent A Dictionary of Plant Pathology .

354532.question: Eucalyptus surrounding an olive grove, next to a main highway in Sicily. Why have the two trees on the left become yellow, one with pronounced leaf loss and sparse growth in the upper crown?
options: Poor soils low alkalinity reduces iron uptake
354532.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus -like particles. Closely associated with this disease , known as Mundulla Yellows yellows . But there are other theories, including poor soils and herbicide damage. Comments on the other options: Im going to stick with the virus -like particles option, partly because the symptoms have that sort of feel: yellowing, unusual growth patterns. Opinion is however divided in the absence of what some say is conclusive proof. Xylella fastidiosa has a huge host range and is a remote possibility  I took this photo from some distance away so didnt have a chance to examine the leaves. The herbicide damage theory gains little support from this site.

357326.question: There is a velvety coating on the underside of these lychee leaves. What is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357326.explanation: The correct answer is: Mites. These are the symptoms of the lychee rust mite. The microscopic mite induces the hair-like outgrowths from the underside of the leaf, among which the mites live.

361086.question: These swellings are often referred to as aerial tubers.  What is the cause of this phenomenon?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
361086.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma complaint. When the phloem is blocked, tubers can begin to develop in the axial buds. These symptoms can be due to Rhizoctonia (fungal) infection or phytoplasma infection.

363755.question: Sooty mould is the black fungus often seen growing on the surface of leaves. The generic name describes a condition rather than a fungal species, but can the fungi be grown in culture?
options: Yes the fungi that make up the sooty mould family can be grown in culture
It is not possible to grow these fungi in culture
Some of the fungi can be grown in culture but not all
They will only grow if honey dew is included in the media
Dont know and dont want to guess
363755.correct_answer: Yes the fungi that make up the sooty mould family can be grown in culture
363755.explanation: The correct answer is: Yes, the fungi that make up the sooty mould family can be grown in culture. Sooty mould is not a true plant pathogen but is growing on the nutrient rich coating that may develop on leaves following a sucking insect attack. They are versatile and will grow on any nutrient rich media.

344550.question: This is an extremely common symptom on the lower leaves of wheat, but which answer is the cause?
options: Natural senescence of the older leaves
I dont know and dont want to guess
344550.explanation: The correct answer is: Zymoseptoria Even if you are not familiar with wheat diseases, you should have been able to get to the correct answer by eliminating the others.  This is Zymoseptoria (previously Septoria). It is an extremely common pathogen on wheat, carried by rain splash. If it reaches the flag leaf, the yield will be considerably reduced. The incorrect answers were: Phytophthora Phytophthoras are mostly pathogens of trees; potato, tomato, capsicum pepper and soybean are the only annual crops where it is usually a problem. Yellow rust Yellow rusts form long stripes of yellow pustules and cause little browning and cell death. (It is still extremely damaging.) Natural senescence of the older leaves. The lower leaves of wheat do senesce as the crop matures but do not do so in patches as seen here.

349781.question: This is a pod bug. The young of this insect resemble which of the following?
options: Similar to the adult but shorter and without wings
Dont know and dont want to guess
349781.correct_answer: Similar to the adult but shorter and without wings
349781.explanation: The correct answer is: Similar to the adult, but shorter and without wings: Pod bugs belong to the Hemiptera, which do not undergo complete metamorphosis during development. The young of Hemiptera often look broadly similar to the adults, but are smaller and often lack wings. The incorrect answers were: Caterpillar: All caterpillars turn into butterflies or moths. Grub: All grubs turn into beetles. Maggot: All maggots turn into flies.

366399.question: Border  inspections Q3 Inspectors are sometimes required to inspect used farm machinery, such as tractors, before it is exported to a different country. For more information https://planthealthportal.defra.gov.uk/trade/exports/exports-to-the-eu/special-export-requirements/exporting-used-agricultural-machinery-to-ni-and-eu/ What do you think the purpose of this type of inspection is? Select one or more
options: To check the machinery underside does not have more than 5 rust
To check the machinery is free from soil andor plant debris
To check the machinery is not leaking fluids for example oil brake fluid or coolant
To check the machinery has not been used to harvest or process Beta vulgaris
To check the machinery is fit for the purpose it has been sold for
366399.correct_answer: To check the machinery is free from soil andor plant debris
366399.explanation: Correct answer: To check the machinery is free from soil and/or plant debris The consignments should meet the requirements of the importing country. For used farm / forestry machinery this is usually that the equipment is free from soil and plant parts and, in some instances, has been treated with an approved disinfectant .

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
