349783.question: These are ergot; fungal material that grows in the ear of cereals in place of the seed material.  Why are ergot such a nuisance for farmers?
options: They are toxic and if present in even modest quantities will render the grain poisonous
They are a missed opportunity for grain production each ergot produced is a loss in yield
They have a bitter taste and will make the grain unpalatable
They will discolour the flour when milled and reduce its value
Dont know and dont want to guess
349783.correct_answer: They are toxic and if present in even modest quantities will render the grain poisonous
349783.explanation: The correct answer is: They are toxic and, if present in even modest quantities, will render the grain poisonous: Ergot are very toxic and must not be eaten. The limits on ergot contamination for animal feed is one per litre of grain, whereas for human consumption, the tolerance is nil. The incorrect answers were: They are a missed opportunity for grain production; each ergot produced is a loss in yield: this is true, but the numbers of ergot never substantially reduce the yield. They have a bitter taste and will make the grain unpalatable: you dont really want to eat one to find out. They will discolour the flour when milled and reduce its value : it is not visible in milled flour. Historically, there are examples of unscrupulous millers selling contaminated flour and, when baked into bread, the whole village dying from the ergot poisoning.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365632.question: Contrast the yield from the infected plant with the healthy on the right.  What kind of problem would cause these symptoms.
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
365632.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection These are the symptoms of Potato spindle tuber viroid (PSTVd).  A viroid is effectively a virus that does not have a protein coat and survives as naked nucleic acid . It is spread via mechanical transmission on tractor wheels and trousers. It can be spread by aphids but only when plants are also infected with Potato leaf roll virus (PLRV).

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365631.question: This photo show ozone damage on a potato leaf. Which leaves are most likely to show damage by ozone?
options: Leaves that have remained wet for prolonged periods
The position or age of the leaf makes no difference the severity of symptoms
I dont know and I dont want to guess
365631.explanation: The correct answer is: Older leaves In all crops it is the older leaves that show symptoms of ozone toxicity .  The most susceptible crops are beans although potatoes are mildly susceptible . Note how clearly defined and lifeless the spots appear indicating an abiotic cause.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357985.question: How many pathogens are infecting this sunflower leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357985.explanation: The correct answer is: Three pathogens. Rust, powdery mildew and Septoria are all infecting this leaf.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360482.question: What is the cause of the spectacular rings on these dahlia leaves?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
360482.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection: Tomato spotted wilt virus has one of the largest host ranges of any plant virus . Here it is attacking dahlia, producing these very interesting symptoms.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340685.question: These Swiss chard leaves have multiple infection sites, the dominant symptom of each is the water soaking. What group of pathogens is most commonly associated with this symptom?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340685.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria: It is common for bacterial infection sites to be water soaked. If a spot is water soaked there is strong probability bacteria are the cause, however, bear in mind that bacterial infections are not always water soaked.  The incorrect answers were: Fungi: leafspots caused by fungi are very rarely water soaked. Water moulds: despite the name, the downy mildews and Phytophthora do not cause water soaked lesions. Viruses: mostly cause leaf distortion and mosaic patterns. They do not cause water soaking.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340699.question: Any cultivation will damage the crop to some extent and should be avoided when the crop is wet. Which group of pathogens will be spread most readily if a crop is cultivated under wet conditions?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340699.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria: often enter plants through small amounts of damage, will be carried on cultivation equipment and thrive under wet conditions. The incorrect answers were: Viruses: very few viruses are transmitted mechanically (although some of them are very important) and there is little evidence that they are readily transmitted through wounds created during cultivation. Some viruses can be transmitted by contact with contaminated equipment. Fungi: most fungi do not generally enter plants through wounds and minor cultivation damage would not spread fungal disease greatly. Nematodes: do not generally infect plants through damage.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

349789.question: These are smut balls on the leaf of an ornamental plant.  Smuts are very specific in which areas of the plant they attack; they are mostly associated with which region of a plant?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
349789.explanation: The correct answer is: Floral parts: As for Ergot (Question 5), smuts usually infect the flowers of a plant and grow down into the ovaries. The incorrect answers were: Roots: Stems: Leaves: Smuts often have complex lifecycles, and there are exceptions to the rule that all smuts infect the floral parts of the plant (see photo above), but there are not many.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

344545.question: What is wrong with these potatoes?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
344545.explanation: The correct answer is: Healthy Despite the obvious purple colour, these potatoes were totally healthy and tasted like the more familiar white potato. The incorrect answers were: Fungal infection There are several fungal pathogens that will infect potato tubers but generally they will cause the tissue to soften and lose structure.  It you look past the colour you can see that the tuber is perfectly fine. Nutrient deficiency Phosphate deficiency will often cause the lower leaves to become reddened (as per question 1) but this does not extend to the tubers. Water mould infection The only water mould that will infect the tubers of potatoes is Phytophthora.  This is definitely not Phytophthora infection; the tissue would be wet and brown, not hard and purple.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

359227.question: What has caused the growth distortion in this lettuce?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359227.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage: It can be difficult to tell what has caused this kind of symptom and it is often necessary to investigate by looking at the spread of symptoms within the field and talking to the farmer. The symptoms look like they could have been caused by a viral infection but there is no yellowing or mosaic which would indicate that is not the case.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

342508.question: These wheat leaves have withered from the tip, what is the likely cause of such a symptom?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
342508.explanation: The correct answer is: Abiotic scorch of some sort. Many things may cause the tips of leaves to die back like this, but the tan colour of the dead region and extreme transition between the dead and healthy tissue indicates scorch.  In this case, the scorch is due to ammonium nitrate solution having been applied when the sun was too strong. The incorrect answers were: Nutrient deficiency : much yellowing occurs. The sharp transition from healthy to dead tissue is not typical of nutrient deficiencies. Insect larvae within the stem: Insect larvae can cause problems in wheat but the symptoms are a general withering of the plant and not the sharp transition between healthy and dead tissue . Bacterial infection: Bacterial infection generally appears wet and, whereas the dead areas here appear very dry, you would rarely see such a marked transition between healthy and dead tissue .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

366401.question: Post-border  surveillance Q1 A UK Plant Passport system is in place for the internal movements of plants. Plant Passports ensure that plants and plant products are traced throughout the supply chain and declare compliance with plant health requirements such as freedom from pests, which is essential for maintaining biosecurity. For more information on Plant Passports, their format and function https://www.gov.uk/guidance/issuing-plant-passports-to-trade-plants-in-great-britain What information should be included under Part D of a Plant Passport?
options: Diseases which the plant may get
Country of Origin of the plant
Conditions where the plant should be grown
I dont know and I dont want to guess
366401.correct_answer: Country of Origin of the plant
366401.explanation: Correct answer : Country of Origin of the plant You must include the country of origin of the consignment a. is the botanical name, b. is the sellers registration number and c. is the traceability code. If you deal with plants professionally you need to be registered with the UK plant health service. Some operators may also need to be authorised to issue plant passports. For more information https://planthealthportal.defra.gov.uk/trade/plant-passports/registration-and-plant-passports/

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

351968.question: What does ULV stand for with regard the application of agro-chemicals?
options: Ultra large V V being the shape of the fan jet emitted from the nozzle
I dont know and I dont want to guess
351968.explanation: The correct answer is: Ultra Low Volume: Application of less than 5L per Hectare (2 L per Acre) on field grown crops is generally considered to be ULV.  There are advantages and disadvantages to using this application technique; ULV sprayers are especially prone to wind drift due to extremely small droplet size.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

358231.question: What is the problem with this young citrus plant?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
358231.explanation: The correct answer is: Pot bound: This plant had outgrown its pot, the lateral roots appear healthy, but the main root growing down doubled back when it could not penetrate the base of the pot.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365340.question: The crazy growth of this asparagus plant is typical of phytoplasma infection but that is not the case here.  What do you think has caused these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
365340.explanation: The correct answer is: Aphid feeding Feeding by the asparagus aphid Brachycorynella asparagi induces this proliferation of leaves

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362996.question: Sweet peppers, Georgia
362996.explanation: The correct answer is: Abiotic Comments: Some years ago I attended the first plant pathology congress held in Georgia (the country). A colleague kindly suggested an agricultural area outside Tbilisi where I might wander round agricultural fields. The farmers were Azeris and I was intrigued at first by an unusual problem on chillies. I explained to the farmer my interest in  diseases and the owner of the field went off to collect a sweet pepper. This is it. He asked me what was wrong with the plant and instead of saying I didnt know I waffled. It could be a disease , I ventured. Too late. I noticed a slight twinkle in his eye as he told me the answer: sunscald.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

356594.question: These symptoms are typical of what problem?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356594.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection: The patchy green and pale green pattern is typical of a viral infection. Often described as a mosaic . The incorrect answers were: Nutrient deficiency: yellow and green regions on the same leaf are typical of some kinds of nutrient deficiency, but the sharp lines between the zones indicate that is not the problem here. Nematode attack: the symptoms of nematode attack are a general yellowing of the plant; some portions will remain green and slowly fade to yellow.  There will never be the sharp lines dividing the colours as seen here. Water mould ( downy mildew ) ; it is common for pale patches to appear on leaves due to downy mildew infection, but here, the whole leaf has become pale with darker green regions.  The sharp lines between the colours indicate this is not due to downy mildew BUT there is an important and common exception to this rule; cucumber downy mildew .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350674.question: Both these lettuces have gone to seed and are no longer edible, but what is causing the distorted growth in the one on the left?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
350674.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection: The distorted growth is typical of a viral infection. The incorrect answers were: Bacterial infection: distorted growth is not associated with bacterial infection. Downy mildew infection : systemic infection by a downy mildew is rare but when it occurs it can distort the leaves, this is not systemic infection by a downy mildew . Nematode infection : wilt and yellowing are the symptoms commonly associated with nematode infection not leaf distortion.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365627.question: Meristem culture is a technique used by those in the seed industry to do what?
options: Provide plants that are free of bacteria
Restore plants to their true genetic type
Remove viruses from the planting material
Generate new mutations for breeding purposes
Dont know and dont want to guess
365627.correct_answer: Remove viruses from the planting material
365627.explanation: The correct answer is: Remove viruses from the planting material The tiny bundle of cells at the very tip of the plant is the only area that remains free of virus . The removal, sterilisation and then growth (on nutrient media) of the tips is the only way to eradicate viruses from potatoes.  The small plants are multiplied in the field many times before being sold as ware potatoes.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357986.question: How many pathogens are causing this symptom on oilseed rape?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357986.explanation: The correct answer is: One pathogen These are the symptoms of Light leafspot on Oilseed rape. The central leaf spot and the small white dots, as satellites of the spot , are all symptoms of Pyrenopeziza brassicae.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364183.question: Which disease spread by bark beetles has led to the significant decline in the populations of elms in the UK?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
364183.explanation: The correct answer is: Ophiostoma novo-ulmi Dutch elm disease is a highly destructive disease of several species of elm (trees in the Ulmus genus ). It is caused by two related fungi, Ophiostoma novo-ulmi and Ophiostoma ulmi, although almost all cases are now caused by O. novo-ulmi . The fungus is spread from tree to tree by elm bark beetles. It has killed tens of millions of elm trees in the United Kingdom since the second wave caused by O. novo-ulmi was accidentally introduced, probably during the 1960s.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355781.question: Coconut palm plantation in Cote dIvoire. Fronds were collapsing all around me, one of the most dramatic examples of a plant health problem I have seen. This problem also found in East Africa, the Caribbean and Central America. Coconuts are attacked by many pests and diseases. Which one? Or is this an abiotic problem?
355781.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma . Lethal yellowing of coconut palms, known locally as St Pauls wilt , is a devastating disease , with variants found around the world. The sudden wilting of the canopy is linked to the ultimate collapse and failure of conducting vessels ( phloem ). Comments on the other options: Rhinoceros beetle is also damaging but crowns tend to become ragged and lack this sudden collapse of fronds. Waterlogging would affect more palm trees at the same time. Fungal root rot is a good guess, and Phytophthora is widespread. Difficult to distinguish without testing of samples.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340696.question: These little leaf symptoms on blackberry are commonly seen in the regrowth of plants following glyphosate treatment (as is the case here). Regrowth after glyphosate treatment is often confused with the infection by which group of pathogens that can produce an almost identical growth habit?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
340696.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasmas: the symptoms of phytoplasma infection can look very similar to the regrowth after Glyphosate treatment. These symptoms are extremely typical of phytoplasma infection. The incorrect answers were: Bacteria: never induce these symptoms. Fungi: fungal infection can induce a witches broom /little leaf symptom but it is an unusual symptom of fungal infection. Nematodes: can stunt plants and the developing leaves may appear smaller but they never induce this dramatic little leaf formation.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

366397.question: Border  inspections Q2 An Inspector working at a UK Border Control Point notices brown to black lesions on the leaves and flowers of a Viburnum tinus (Laurustinus or cramp-bark). They suspect they are caused by a particular quarantine pest or disease, so a sample is taken for diagnosis. What do you suspect is wrong with the plant?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
366397.explanation: Correct answer : Phytophthora ramorum Samples are taken whenever the presence of a quarantine pest or disease is suspected, and sent to a laboratory for an official diagnosis , as plant health inspectors are not trained diagnosticians. Even in cases where the inspector is confident of the diagnosis samples are still sent to a laboratory for confirmation. For further information on FERAs activities: https://www.fera.co.uk/ Sample packaging: https://www.fera.co.uk/crop-health/sample-shipping-information

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

349779.question: All you can see here is a leafspot.  Although you know nothing of the host plant, you should be able to determine the cause.  Which of these is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
349779.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungus: These are leaf spots caused by Septoria on a floating water weed.  Septoria is a Coelomycete fungus which means it makes these little black fruiting bodies within the leafspot. Zymoseptoria is a common pathogen on wheat and these pycnidia can usually be seen within leafspots at the base of wheat plants. The incorrect answers were: Insect feeding: rarely causes necrosis most sucking insects leave no mark on the leaves. Water mould: they sporulate as, either: 1) microscopic hard oospores that cannot be seen, as they are too tiny and are deep within the tissue , or 2) as fluffy growth, usually on the underside of leaves. Rust fungus: this specialist fungal group does not create leaf spots and the host tissue will only become necrotic (dead) once the host can no longer support the demands of the pathogen .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357686.question: These are the cut fruit from a wilting banana plant in Uganda. Wilting was seen in young, emerging leaves, which gradually went from pale green to brown. What is the cause?
357686.explanation: The correct answer is: Xanthomonas bacterial wilt of banana Comments on the other options: Fusarium wilt affects older leaves and does not, usually, affect fruits. Xanthomonas wilt produces this distinctive staining in fruits and premature ripening (as does Ralstonia bacterial wilt  Moko disease ). Fusarium wilted leaves are older and often go a bright yellow.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352210.question: What are these yellow balls attached to the potato roots?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
352210.explanation: The correct answer is: Cysts: These are the cysts of the potato cyst nematode .  They are attached to roots just like nematode galls, but, unlike a gall , they are not made up of the plant tissue ; this is the swollen body of the female nematode , packed full of eggs. The incorrect answers were: Galls: these are commonly associated with nematode infection (but not all nematodes cause galls). Cysts are much smaller than galls and are always of extremely similar size and appear clean, despite being in the soil. Eggs: difficult to imagine what animal would have laid eggs in this haphazard way, most insects / animals will lay eggs bunched tightly together. Sclerotia: they are always black and usually formed within the tissue and (it is difficult to tell) are much larger than nematode cysts.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357004.question: Galls such as these on leaves are typically formed by mites but that is not the case here.  What do you think has caused these galls to form on this grapevine leaf?
options: An aphid type insect called Phylloxera
I dont know and I dont want to guess
357004.correct_answer: An aphid type insect called Phylloxera
357004.explanation: The correct answer is: An aphid type insect called Phylloxera: Very unusual symptom this pest has devastated the grape industry in the late 19 th century. Nematodes very rarely attack leaves and when they do the do not form galls. Bacterial galls are rarely found on leaves and they turn brown as they develop. Downy mildews do not form galls.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360480.question: What has damaged this rose tip?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
360480.explanation: The correct answer is: Thrips: Thrips can get into the apex of a plant and the feeding may cause the developing leaves to appear distorted once they have expanded.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350673.question: This wheat ear is infected by Fusarium, why can this disease be such a problem for wheat farmers?
options: Yield reduction due to the infection of the ear
Mycotoxin production by the fungus causing the wheat to be unsafe to eat
Allows other more damaging pathogens to enter the ear
Will return to the soil where it will cause root disease next year
Dont know and dont want to guess
350673.correct_answer: Mycotoxin production by the fungus causing the wheat to be unsafe to eat
350673.explanation: The correct answer is: Mycotoxin production by the fungus causing the wheat to be unsafe to eat: Infection of the ear will lead to mycotoxin production in the grain. These mycotoxins are usually present at extremely low levels but are extremely toxic.  They cause cancer at low concentrations and rapid death at higher concentrations. Wheat rarely has sufficient concentrations to cause immediate death but that is not the case with poorly stored maize. The incorrect answers were: Yield reduction due to the infection of the ear : this will have an effect but is relatively small compared to the effect of toxin accumulation. Allows other more damaging pathogens to enter the ear : there is no evidence that this is the case. Will return to the soil where it will cause root disease next year : Fusaria are fungi that survive well in the soil but that is not the primary problem with ear infection of wheat.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357325.question: What is the material on the upper surface of these plants?
options: There is no material that is natural colour of the leaf
Dont know and dont want to guess
357325.explanation: The correct answer is: Roadside dust. These beans were planted close to a very dusty road and became coated in dust. Note that the colour of the leaves is the same as the soil.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357687.question: The bark has been removed from this cacao tree in DRC. Above ground some branches are dying and leaves are dropping. What is the cause of the decline?
357687.explanation: The correct answer is: Armillaria root rot . Comments on the other options: It looks like a boring insect, yet the extensive white mycelium gives the game away. Armillaria is truly impressive in the number of species it can affect. Its not a serious disease in eastern DRC, but one to look out for when diagnosing Verticillium wilt , a more common and serious problem.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352374.question: Which pathogen does not require wet conditions and will thrive in dry sunny weather?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
352374.explanation: The correct answer is: Powdery mildew : They are very unusual pathogens and will prosper under dry conditions.  Free water will actually inhibit the germination of powdery mildew spores. The incorrect answers were: Downy mildew ; all downy mildews require free water and high humidity to grow and spread. Bacterial disease ; bacterial diseases are seldom a problem in dry weather. Rusts; once inside the leaf, rust pustules will develop within a dry leaf, but spore germination requires free water.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357984.question: These are barley leaves; how many pathogens are involved here?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357984.explanation: The correct answer is: There is no pathogen involved Incredible as it may seem, there is no pathogen infection on these leaves.  The necrotic areas are generally described as stress symptoms but they can develop even in the absence of any apparent stress on the plant.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

344552.question: Tilt super is a locally made (and branded) product within SEA that contains both Propiconazole and Difenoconazole. What is wrong with this blend?
options: Two chemicals with the same mode of action will not help to prevent resistance in the pathogen population
The chemicals are both systemic and it is preferable to have contact and systemic mix
The chemicals are considered to be old and newer ones are available
The chemicals will counteract each other and effectively cancel each other out
I dont know and dont want to guess
344552.correct_answer: Two chemicals with the same mode of action will not help to prevent resistance in the pathogen population
344552.explanation: The correct answer is: Two chemicals with the same mode of action will not help to prevent resistance in the pathogen population. It is always a good idea to blend fungicides to prevent resistance developing in the pathogen population, but if the two chemicals are from the same resistance group, resistance can still develop. The incorrect answers were: The chemicals are both systemic and it is preferable to have contact and systemic mix. It is common practice to blend a systemic chemical with a contact one. This is usually done to get the benefit of the systemic action with the economy of the contact. The chemicals are considered to be old and newer ones are available. The triazole group of fungicides have been available for several decades but they are still an important aspect of disease control. The chemicals will counteract each other and effectively cancel each other out. There is no suggestion that this is correct; both chemicals will stay active (until resistance develops).

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364186.question: A fungal pathogen on cedars  (Cedrus) can cause a shoot blight and cankers as well as a shoot blight on hemlock (Tsuga spp.).  One of the most conspicuous symptoms of this disease on Atlas cedar is a pink colouration of the needle between June and July.  What is the pathogen?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364186.explanation: The correct answer is: Sirococcus tsugae : Sirococcus tsugae is a fungal pathogen that causes shoot blight and cankers on cedar trees ( Cedrus spp.), and shoot blight on hemlock ( Tsuga spp.). It can attack seedlings and saplings as well as mature trees. This pathogen has the potential to cause considerable damage to valuable ornamental trees in public and private gardens and economic losses for the forestry and nursery sectors in the UK.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

363765.question: Xylella fastidiosa is a Xylem-Limited Bacterial Pathogen of Plants which has no capacity in the wild to survive outside a host plant or insect vector, however, can it be cultured?
options: No Xylella cannot be grown in culture
Yes Xylella will grow on any microbial medium
It is possible to culture Xylella on special media
It can be cultured but only when supported by insect salivary glands
363765.correct_answer: It is possible to culture Xylella on special media
363765.explanation: The correct answer is: It is possible to culture Xylella on special media. There is special medium that will support the growth of Xylella, it  grows slowly and produces small colonies..

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

342533.question: It is well known that aphids are common vectors of plant viruses but how long after feeding on an infected plant does the aphid retain the ability to inoculate other plants?
options: The aphid always will carry the virus and will inoculate other plants for the remainder of its life
The aphid always will lose the virus and will not spread it after a few hours
The aphid will always lose the virus and will not spread it after a few days
The length of time the aphid remains able to transmit the virus depends on the virus  vector combination
I dont know and I dont want to guess
342533.correct_answer: The length of time the aphid remains able to transmit the virus depends on the virus  vector combination
342533.explanation: The correct answer is: The length of time the aphid remains able to transmit the virus depends on the virus / vector combination. The ability of the aphid to transmit the virus , which is technically the length of time it remains v iliferous, depends on the virus and species of aphid. The aphid may remain viliferous for a few minutes or it may be for weeks. The incorrect answers were: The aphid will always carry the virus (and will inoculate other plants) for the remainder of its life; this is unusual in aphid/ virus combinations but it is true in some cases . The aphid will lose the virus and will not spread it after a few hours; this is true in many aphid virus combinations. The aphid will lose the virus and will not spread it after a few days; this is true in many aphid virus combinations

366390.question: Pre-border  intelligence Q3 The UK has a robust biosecurity regime, the importance and value of which is highlighted by the example of the Asian longhorn beetle, Anoplophora glabripennis . The UK has had a single, small outbreak which occurred in 2012. We surveyed, undertook winter tree inspections and summer pheromone tracking, for a further seven years, to cover three life cycles, with eradication being declared in 2019. Further information on the UK outbreak available at https://cabiagbio.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s43170-021-00034-x How much did the UK eradication cost?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
366390.explanation: Correct answer: Around 2 million. Asian longhorn beetle is a highly destructive insect pest which poses a serious threat to a wide range of broadleaf trees, including species grown commercially for timber and fruit production. For more information on ALB: https://www.forestresearch.gov.uk/tools-and-resources/fthr/pest-and-disease-resources/asian-longhorn-beetle-anoplophora-glabripennis/

365630.question: Rust mite damage is an unusual symptom of potato and does not occur in many areas? Why are rust mites so often misdiagnosed?
options: The symptoms are typical of many types of disorder
The mites are so tiny they cannot be seen
The discolouration of the leaves can appear like natural senescence
The symptoms are typical of nutrient disorder
I dont know and I dont want to guess
365630.correct_answer: The mites are so tiny they cannot be seen
365630.explanation: The correct answer is: The mites are so tiny they cannot be seen. Most pests can be seen with the naked eye or at least with a hand lens.  Inspection of plants infested with rust mites will reveal nothing, often leading to a misdiagnosis.

364182.question: Staying with ash, what do this picture show?
364182.explanation: The correct answer is: Ash keys The seeds produced by ash trees are known as ash keys and they typically hang in a bundle.  As they mature the colour changes from green to brown.  At this point they can be easily confused for wilting leaves which is a symptom of Chalara ash dieback .

348215.question: The central portion of this tomato stem has died and within it are black lumps.  This leaves little doubt as to the cause. What is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
348215.explanation: The correct answer is: Sclerotinia sclerotiorum A very common fungal disease , which often attacks the base of plants; it is one of the few plant pathogens that will develop an extensive network of hyphae outside the plant. The incorrect answers were: Bacterial wilt Bacterial wilt can cause wilting and necrosis above the site of infection (it usually spreads to all of the plant quickly) but it never produces these black structures seen within the stem. Phytophthora infestans (Late blight ) The upper leaves have died but the lower leaves show symptoms which would be very unusual for this pathogen . Phytophthora resting spores are too small see with the naked eye and P. infestans does not produce them in many countries. Tomato spotted wilt virus The symptoms of TSWV are mostly ringspots and rarely a wilt . Viruses never produce structures visible to the naked eye.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350679.question: This is the upper surface of a grapevine leaf infected with downy mildew. Under what conditions does the characteristic downy growth appear on the undersurface of the leaf?
options: When free water has splashed up onto the underside of the leaf
I dont know and I dont want to guess
350679.explanation: The correct answer is: High humidity: The conditions for the sporulation (production of downy growth) are high humidity and darkness. The darkness is pretty well guaranteed at night unless the leaves are in experimental conditions. High humidity often occurs when there has been rainfall and then the temperature drops. To test for a downy mildew , put a symptomatic leaf in a plastic bag overnight in the dark and look for sporulation in the morning. The incorrect answers were: High temperature, high light: the downy mildews do not thrive in such conditions and the infected areas often turn necrotic and die. Low temperature; low light: under these conditions it is likely that sporulation will occur due to the concurrent increase in relative humidity but it is the humidity that is the important factor. When free water has splashed up onto the underside of the leaf: the downy mildews will not sporulate into free water, the leaf must be dry.

356602.question: Why are there no parasites of aphid eggs?
options: They are defended by the mother aphid
They are too small to be parasitised
I dont know and dont want to guess
356602.explanation: The correct answer is: Aphids dont lay eggs: Aphids give birth to live young, they do not lay eggs. That is one reason why the populations can rise so rapidly. The incorrect answers were: See above.

354526.question: Neem trees are common through the dryer, dusty zones of West Africa. This tree is from Niger. What has caused the death of these leaves?
354526.explanation: The correct answer is: Fire damage. This symptom really confused me when I carried out a survey of neem pests and diseases in Niger and Nigeria in the 1990s. Yet looking at afresh it is much clearer that someone has lit a fire below. Comments on the other options: Stem borers could cause such symptoms, but not here. The leaves have died suddenly and in a defined area  not an indication of a wilt pathogen . High winds can damage leaves, with the margins drying up and browning. Symptoms would be less severe and more diffuse in a larger area of the crown.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

351969.question: Does compost made from diseased plants contain diseases from the original plant material?
options: Yes the pathogens will survive and will infect any susceptible crop when compost is applied to the soil
The heat generated by the composting process will kill the pathogen spores
Biocontrol will take place within the composting process and the fungal pathogens will rot along with the plant material
Some pathogens will survive but most will not due to the length of time the composting process takes
I dont know and dont want to guess
351969.correct_answer: The heat generated by the composting process will kill the pathogen spores
351969.explanation: The correct answer is: The heat generated by the composting process will kill the pathogen spores: If done correctly, the heat from the pile will kill the spores of pathogens. Larger piles are better as they have less surface to volume ratio.  Also, shallow compost areas are ineffective; compost should be kept heaped-up to better retain core heat. The incorrect answers were: Yes, the pathogens will survive and will infect any susceptible crop when compost is applied to the soil; this is not true if the composting process is done correctly. Biocontrol will take place within the composting process and the fungal pathogens will rot along with the plant material; this is not true and the resting fungal spores are highly resistant to rotting. Some pathogens will survive but most will not due to the length of time the composting process takes; composting should only take a few months and fungal resting spores will survive much longer than that.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352204.question: What is the best term to describe this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352204.explanation: The correct answer is: Wilt : This is a common symptom caused by abiotic factors, insects and pathogens.  It always refers to a drooping of the leaves due to a lack of water in the leaves. Woody tissue cannot wilt as the structure is not maintained through water pressure, however the leaves on a woody branch may wilt . The incorrect answers were: Flaccid: it is true that the leaves are flaccid, but that is not the usual word to describe a plant in this state. Collapsed: wilt is a far better word to describe the symptom . Drooped: yes, the plant is drooped, but wilt is a much better description because it indicates why the plant is drooped (lack of water in the leaves).

362712.question: What causes these symptoms on runner/french beans.
362712.explanation: The correct answer is Biotic . This is Bean mosaic virus . Note the distinctive markings on the leaf and loss of colour

362716.question: More strange growth, this time on tomato plants in a polytunnel.
362716.explanation: The correct answer is Abiotic . Once you become familiar with phytoplasma symptoms theres an early tendency to see them everywhere. Common sense suggests that this is an unlikely explanation for small, stunted leaves. This is in fact glyphosate (weedkiller) damage.

355782.question: Detached branches of Gliricidia sepium, a widespread agroforestry species in tropical regions. Compare the unhealthy, yellowed foliage on the left with the normal growth next to it. Both occur on the same tree. The symptoms are distributed unequally throughout the crown. Some of the branches have started to die.
355782.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma . Look at the clumped growth, reduced internode length and reduced leaflet size. The difference between unhealthy and normal growth is stark and dramatic  a good starting point for thinking  phytoplasma  Comments on the other options: Yes, its similar to herbicide damage  but drift is unlikely to reach the top parts of the crown. Virus infection is also a possibility; distinguishing little leaves from reduced growth is not easy and requires close examination (even then Im easily confused).

361084.question: Why are viral pathogens such a threat to a potato crop?  Note the distortion due to PVY infection on the leaves on the right.
options: The vegetative propagation of potatoes allows them to build up
Potatoes are particularly susceptible to aphids which are good vectors of viruses
The potato crop shows unusually severe symptoms relative to other crops
Potatoes are particularly susceptible to viral pathogens
I dont know and dont want to guess
361084.correct_answer: The vegetative propagation of potatoes allows them to build up
361084.explanation: The correct answer is: The vegetative propagation of potatoes allows them to build up:. Plant viruses are seldom seed borne. As potatoes are propagated vegetatively, in the form of tubers, they will accumulate viruses year on year.

351967.question: Netting is sometimes used to keep insect pests and birds out of an area. Are nets ever used to keep pathogens out of a crop?
options: The netting has to be fine but it can be used to stop windblown fungal spores
Nets are never used to keep out pathogens
The netting has to be fine but it can be used to stop bacterial pathogens
There are occasions when nets can be used to keep pathogens out of a crop
I dont know and dont want to guess
351967.correct_answer: There are occasions when nets can be used to keep pathogens out of a crop
351967.explanation: The correct answer is: There are occasions when nets can be used to keep pathogens out of a crop: This may be a bit of a trick question, but there are occasions when insect vectored viruses are kept out of a crop (such as seed potato production) with netting. It is the virus that is being excluded which happens to be inside an insect. The incorrect answers were: The netting has to be fine but it can be used to stop wind-blown fungal spores; no, the mesh would have to be so fine that light would not pass through. Nets are never used to keep out pathogens; there are occasions, see above . The netting has to be fine but it can be used to stop bacterial pathogens; no, the mesh would have to be so fine that light would not pass through. Photo courtesy of Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

363384.question: These (right) are the symptoms of PVY (Potato virus Y).  How accurate can a field diagnosis be of this pathogen based on these leaves?
options: Characteristic symptoms and a firm diagnosis could be made in the field
Diagnosis would be possible after microscopic examination
It may be possible to suggest PVY but not possible to make a firm diagnosis
Not possible to make any sort of diagnosis in the field
Dont know and dont want to guess
363384.correct_answer: It may be possible to suggest PVY but not possible to make a firm diagnosis
363384.explanation: The correct answer is: It may be possible to suggest PVY but not possible to make a firm diagnosis . Field diagnoses can be accurate and precise but the symptoms of viral infection on potatoes can be tricky unless you are very experienced.  It should be possible to suggest that PVY is one of the potential causes.

364668.question: Spraying fungicides at below their recommended rate will have what effect on the resistance in the fungal population?
options: It will rapidly lead to resistance
It will have no effect on the development of resistance
Reduced doses are generally helpful in reducing selection pressure and delaying the emergence of resistance
It will depend on the timing and the crop being sprayed
Dont know and dont want to guess
364668.correct_answer: Reduced doses are generally helpful in reducing selection pressure and delaying the emergence of resistance
364668.explanation: The correct answer is: Reduced doses are helpful in reducing selection pressure and delaying the emergence of resistance . Possibly counter intuitively most examples in the literature suggest that reduced doses are helpful in reducing selection pressure and delaying the emergence of resistance . What you must not do (with regard resistance ) to in increase the dose in an attempt to overcome the resistance developing in a population. That will really ramp up the resistance .

356595.question: Hoverfly, seen here, are often considered to be the gardeners friend as they are well known natural enemies of pests, but what do the adult hoverfly eat?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356595.explanation: The correct answer is: Nectar pollen and honeydew: The adults are not the natural enemies; it is the larvae that are voracious predators. The incorrect answers were: Aphids; are the main food of hoverfly larvae Mealybugs; not eaten by hoverfly larvae Caterpillars; not eaten by hoverfly larvae

357330.question: What is growing on the surface of this leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357330.explanation: The correct answer is: Lichen. Not normally a problem in crop production, lichen can grow epiphytically on leaves. As they grow slowly, only older leaves will accrue a lichen population.

348213.question: This is Late blight on tomato again, but looking rather different from usual. The lesions are dry, tan coloured and no longer seem to be spreading. Why have these symptoms developed?
options: High temperatures and dry weather after the initial infection
This is a resistant variety this is a resistant reaction
Biological control of the pathogen is taking place
These are early symptoms and will develop into more characteristic symptoms with time
I dont know and I dont want to guess
348213.correct_answer: High temperatures and dry weather after the initial infection
348213.explanation: The correct answer is: High temperatures and dry weather after the initial infection. Foliar-attacking Phytophthora require warm and wet weather to thrive. In this case, the weather became very hot and very dry, and the Phytophthora has died. The lesions have been taken over by a saprobe and is sporulating in some cases. The incorrect answers were: This is a resistant variety; this is a resistant reaction. No; this was a very susceptible reaction and, if the weather had not changed, the whole leaf would have died. Biological control of the pathogen is taking place. Saprobes have moved in on the dead tissue but that is not what killed the leaf tissue (or killed the Phytophthora) These are early symptoms and will develop into more characteristic symptoms with time. No; early symptoms of Phytophthora infection are pale, sunken patches on the leaf which rapidly turn black.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365349.question: What has caused the symptoms on this developing cashew nut?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365349.explanation: The correct answer is: Insect feeding. Insect feeders that are considered sucking pests often leave no symptoms whatsoever however the leaf footed bug ( Pseudotheraptus wayi) along with many other capsids leave necrotic tissue behind after feeding as seen here.

351961.question: Necrotroph is a common description of a type of plant pathogen, but what does it actually mean?  This photo is of Botrytis allii infecting onion.
options: It describes the fungal group that the pathogen is in
It means that the pathogen will only grow on material that has died previously
It means that the pathogen will rot the host plant
It means that the pathogen kills the host tissue before colonising it
I dont know and dont want to guess
351961.correct_answer: It means that the pathogen kills the host tissue before colonising it
351961.explanation: The correct answer is: It means that the pathogen kills the host tissue before colonising it. Necrotroph is the opposite of a biotroph; a necrotrophic pathogen will use an arsenal of toxins and enzymes to overpower the hosts defences and kill the tissue ahead of the advancing fungal mycelium . The incorrect answers were: It describes the fungal group that the pathogen is in; the fact that the fungus is a necrotroph has no bearing on the classification (for example genus /species) of the pathogen . It means that the pathogen will only grow on material that has died previously; fungi that grow on dead material are generally described as saprobes or saprophytes.  They are generally not pathogens but are opportunistic / imposter pathogens. It means that the pathogen will rot the host plant ; almost all necrotrophs do rot the host tissue , as it is often killed with host cell wall degrading enzymes, but that is not what the term means.

356598.question: This is a very characteristic symptom of peach leaf curl; a common complaint of stone fruit.  It is caused by a fungus; however, these are extremely unusual symptoms of a fungal infection and are more typical of what problem or pest?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356598.explanation: The correct answer is: Mites: As stated in the question, this leaf distortion is due to a fungal pathogen ( Taphrina deformans ). These symptoms are more typical of the distortion sometimes caused by mites. The incorrect answers were: Scale insect; never induces leaf distortion. Downy mildew ; can occasionally produce very limited leaf distortion Viral infection; can distort leaves but the whole leaf would generally be affected

352208.question: What is the name generally given to the yellow zone around the infection site?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
352208.explanation: The correct answer is: Halo : This phrase is used to describe the distressed host tissue at the edge of a leaf spot .  It is almost always yellow as seen here. The incorrect answers were: Corona: this is not a term used in plant pathology . Border: the yellow halo is generally considered to be outside the border of the leaf spot . Toxin zone: there may be toxins leaching out into the host tissue creating the halo , but that is not what it is called.

358237.question: What is this growing inside this tomato stem?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
358237.explanation: The correct answer is: Adventitious roots The roots seen here were found growing inside the slightly swollen stem of a tomato plant.  The swelling appeared to be associated with Fusarium infection (comments welcome).

357328.question: What is the material on the upper surface of these leaves?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess

359223.question: What is seen on the upper and lower surface of this lettuce leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359223.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew sporulation Its unusual to see a downy mildew sporulating without causing any host reaction, as seen here.  Similarly, it is unusual to see downy mildew sporulation on the upper and lower leaf surface, but that is what is taking place. Bremia lactucae ( downy mildew of lettuce).

351965.question: BT is a chemical produced by a bacterium which is extremely toxic to the larvae of butterflies and moths. When sprayed as a chemical on the crop, what effect will this have on the populations of their natural enemies?
options: It will have no effect as there are no natural enemies that are in the moth family
The spray will kill the predators as they may be eating the already poisoned larvae
The predator population will increase because the toxic chemical will make the prey easier to catch
The populations will decline simply because the food source will be reduced
I dont know and I dont want to guess
351965.correct_answer: The populations will decline simply because the food source will be reduced
351965.explanation: The correct answer is: The populations will decline simply because the food source will be reduced: The BT chemical will kill the larvae which will reduce (or eliminate) their food source. The natural enemies will either leave or die. The incorrect answers were: It will have no effect as there are no natural enemies that are in the moth family; whilst there are no natural enemies in the moth family, the population will reduce as the food supply will vanish. The spray will kill the predators as they may be eating the already poisoned larvae; the BT has a rapid knock-down action and the predators will not eat dead prey . The predator population will increase because the toxic chemical will make the prey easier to catch ; there is generally no problem with predators catching their prey and the BT will not slow the prey down (they are caterpillars after all). It will kill them rapidly and reduce the amount of food for natural enemies.

361423.question: These are viral ringspots on rhubarb. Which viral vector is commonly associated with viruses that cause ringspots such as these?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
361423.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode : Nepoviruses are spread by nematodes and often induce ringspots in the host.

362715.question: Why have some potato leaves gone yellow?
362715.explanation: The correct answer is Biotic . The distribution of symptoms in the field suggests a specific cause rather than a general lack of nutrients, for example. This is mop top virus .

363140.question: Onion downy mildew:  What are the concentric rings of and yellow and green more typically associated with?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
363140.explanation: The correct answer is: The concentric rings seen on this onion leaf are typical of a viral ringspot. The fluffy purple growth in the centre of the spot leaves no doubt as to the cause of the problem.

355521.question: Friend or foe?  Some large insects are predators of pests, what are your thoughts on this one?
options: Foe this is a pest of crops
Friend this is clearly a predator of pests
Neither this large insect is not a problem nor is it a beneficial
Vector  it is not a pest directly but spreads viruses which damage yield
I dont know and dont want to guess
355521.correct_answer: Foe this is a pest of crops
355521.explanation: The correct answer is: Foe; this is a pest of crops: This is the Giant tip wilter, a pest of passion fruit. Enzymes are injected into the stems which causes them to wilt rapidly. The incorrect answers were: Friend; this is clearly a predator of pests. Neither; this large insect is not a problem, nor is it a beneficial. 346537.question: This is Cercospora ablemoschi growing on the underside of okra leaves. The symptoms are typical of this disease, but not typical of Cercospora fungi in general.  Which of the following is more typical of Cercospora infection?
options: Mosaic or mottle often more pronounced on the older leaves
Dont know and dont want to guess
346537.explanation: The correct answer is: Well-defined leaf spots The leaf spots typical of Cercospora infection often have all the characteristics of a typical fungal leaf spot : limited size with a clear, distinct border, evenly distributed across the leaf surface. The incorrect answers were: White powdery growth You may be thinking of the powdery mildews. These are the only fungi that produce white powder in substantial quantities. Wet and slimy rot Cercosporas will kill the leaf tissue , but it generally remains hard and dry within the leaf spot . Mosaic or mottle, often more pronounced on the older leaves These symptoms are not associated with Cercospora infection.

355780.question: Maize in South Africa, photographed by my colleague Wilmarie Kriel. Whats the cause of this grassy-like bundle?
355780.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew or crazy top of maize, caused by Sclerophthora macrospora . Comments on the other options: There are many viruses on maize with common leaf symptoms such as streaks, mottles and so on. Not grassy clusters. There are two phytoplasma diseases I know of on maize, one causing reddening and the other stunting . Lack of nutrients is a diagnosis of last resort, mainly, I suspect, because of a lack of awareness of less well known causes e.g. downy mildew .

363377.question: Potato roots but what are the lumps?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363377.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode galls These are galls on potatoes caused by Meloidogyne species.  The potato cyst nematode is a big problem in potato production but the cysts are tiny and on the side of the root (and all the same size)

362719.question: What are these strange growths on Mountain papaya caused by?
362719.explanation: The correct answer is Biotic . Vasconcellea pubescens looks like normal papaya except it can grow up to 3000 masl in Colombia. There are at least two possible reasons for these bud massess or malformations: fungus (mango malformation looks similar and is caused by Fusarium spp.); or phytoplasma . Or it could be induced by insect feeding. Either way, it definitely looks biotic .

362030.question: A common feature on garlic, onions and leeks.
362030.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: These are the pustules of a rust ( Puccinia porrii ). Look out for it on wild garlic, now flowering profusely

356600.question: What group of pathogens are causing this problem?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356600.explanation: The correct answer is: Water mould ( downy mildew ): In cool damp weather, downy mildews will sporulate profusely on the underside of the leaf and may cause some necrosis .  In hot sunny weather they will induce much greater necrosis and sporulation is much reduced. The incorrect answers were: Virus ; never produce spreading lesions such as these. Fungus; the symptoms could be seen as fungal, but note the sporulation on the underside of the leaf, something that fungi rarely do. Bacterial; the sporulation clearly indicates that this is not a bacterial infection.

348212.question: Wild oats in an oat crop; what is it about wild oats that make them such a problem?
options: The seeds contaminate the harvest reducing its quality
They carry diseases over season to season making crop rotation redundant
They take up a lot of room and will crowd out the crop
The seeds are shed before the combine harvests the crop and do not contribute to the yield
I dont know and dont want to guess
348212.correct_answer: They take up a lot of room and will crowd out the crop
348212.explanation: The correct answer is: They take up a lot of room and will crowd out the crop. The main problem with wild oats among the crop is that; they are extremely large plants that grow very quickly, will shade the crop and remove water and nutrients from the soil. They also produce thousands of seeds which can be dormant, making them a very difficult weed to control. The incorrect answers were: The seeds contaminate the harvest, reducing its quality. Unless the harvest is being saved for seed, this is not a problem. They carry diseases over season to season, making crop rotation redundant. This may be true to a limited extent, but is not foremost in farmers minds when they are battling wild oats. The seeds are shed before the combine harvests the crop and do not contribute to the yield. This is usually true, but it is not the missing yield that is the problem.

354533.question: These dense massess in the crowns are a common feature of birches, seen here in Abinger Hammer in Surrey. What are they?
354533.explanation: The correct answer is: Taphrina betulina . Yes, fungi can cause witches brooms and other strange growths, such as peach leaf curl (also a Taphrina sp. ) and  my favourite  mango malformation (Fusarium!). Comments on the other options: Too many, wrong shape and too densely packed to be birds nests (says a self-confessed non-birder). Yes, phytoplasmas do frequently induce witches brooms, but not on birch. Mistletoes are green, are more regular in shape and less dense.

361085.question: What has caused these symptoms in the tip of this potato plant?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
361085.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide . Potatoes are difficult to kill with herbicide as they often have considerable underground reserves. Glyphosate will kill them, but it requires a considerable dose.  This yellowing at the base of the leaves is the symptom of a glyphosate treated potato plant.

360095.question: This symptom is often confused with downy mildew.  This is rust mite on grapevine but why would you not be able to see the mites if you were to examine closely?
options: They are too small to be seen except with a high power light microscope
They will have left the region once the symptoms appear
The mites are not located near the symptoms
They hide away from the feeding zones during the day
Dont know and dont want to guess
360095.correct_answer: They are too small to be seen except with a high power light microscope
360095.explanation: The correct answer is: They are too small to be seen except with a high power light microscope: There are two types of mite that frequently attack plants, the larger, highly mobile, web-producing red spider type of mite and the much smaller, eriophyid mite which looks like a hermit crab in an ice cream cone. These are much smaller and very difficult to see.

363758.question: Tobacco mosaic virus (virions seen here) is unusual in that it has considerable ability to survive on inanimate surfaces., how does it respond in culture?
options: Will selfassemble and grow into minute colonies provided RNA bases are provided
Will grow provided a filter sterilised plant extract is provided
Will grow on nutrient rich media but the colonies are too small to see
Dont know and dont want to guess
363758.explanation: The correct answer is: Does not grow in culture: Although TMV is able to survive outside a host plant cell the replication of the virus is intimately associated with the metabolism of the living cell, and it will never replicate in culture.

360483.question: This is black pod disease on cocoa.  It is one of the few examples of above-ground infection of which kind of pathogen?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360483.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytophthoras: Late blight on potato and tomato is an extremely common disease , but there are relatively few other common examples of Phytophthora attacking above ground, they are mostly pathogens of roots and lower stems.  Here we see Phytophthora palmivora attacking the cocoa pods.

362032.question: Late season rhubarb from a trial plot at Wisley (Royal Horticultural Society) in the UK. What is the general category of cause?
362032.explanation: The correct answer is: Confused Comments: It could be a root pathogen , or even a virus (rhubarb has lots of them), but I think this is just leaves dying off at the end of the growing season. Perhaps not so confusing for RHS plant health specialists who tend trials.

365628.question: What is this disease?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
365628.explanation: The correct answer is: Potato wart disease : These dramatic symptoms are due to Synchytrium endobioticum a chytrid fungus. It is seldom seen as it is a notifiable disease in many countries and it is illegal to grow potatoes on infected land. Believe it or not these symptoms are mild compared to some infections.

359225.question: What is the cause of this leaf vein crinkling?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
359225.explanation: The correct answer is: Physiological condition; no pathogen involved Thickening, deformity and roughening of leaf texture in lettuce can all occur in response to cold temperatures.  If the tissue is killed it will begin to decay.

362039.question: A punnet of strawberries with many unsuitable for sale.
362039.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: This could just be a tray of squashed and rotting strawberries, but note the grey mould on several fruits. Botrytis is a big problem for commercial growers.

359634.question: Mistletoe is green and can photosynthesise. What effect does it have on the host tree?
options: It has a very damaging impact on the health of the plant but localised to the place of infection
It just uses the tree for support and does not damage it
It will grow down into the roots and kill the tree
Mistletoe is beneficial and increases the growth of the plant
I dont know and dont want to guess
359634.correct_answer: It has a very damaging impact on the health of the plant but localised to the place of infection
359634.explanation: The correct answer is: It has a very damaging impact on the health of the plant but localised to the place of infection. Despite the ability of mistletoe to photosynthesise, it does draw a lot of photosynthate and minerals from the host tree. Epiphytes are plants that use larger plants for support, but this is a parasitic plant, draining resources from the tree.

361418.question: What kind of insect is this rhubarb pest?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
361418.explanation: The correct answer is: Coleopteran: Coleoptera is the Latin name for the beetle family of which weevils are a subset. This is the adult rhubarb curculio Lixus concavus. It feeds on rhubarb and lays eggs on rhubarb but the eggs laid in rhubarb do not hatch, but are killed by the sap or crushed by the developing tissues. The plant that supports the growth of the larvae are dock plants.

352211.question: What is the correct name for this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352211.explanation: The correct answer is: Gummosis : When damaged by a pest , pathogen or even mechanical damage, some trees will start to produce resinous sap which will dribble down the trunk.  The technical word for this is  gummosis . The incorrect answers were: Ooze: often called ooze, but this is not the correct term. Bleeding: often called bleeding, but this is not the correct term. Resination : this is a word I have just made up, no-one calls it resination.

362990.question: Maize growing at RHS Wisley
362990.explanation: The correct answer is: Varietal characteristic Comments: The red lines are regular and the leaves are healthy. Im familiar with phosphorus deficiency (red to purple streaks) and this is not it  nor would I expect a nutrient deficiency at Wisley!

361090.question: Killing the potato tops mechanically, or chemically, prior to lifting the potatoes, is good for disease control but there is another aspect of potato production that requires the tops to be killed prior to lifting. Why are the above-ground potato plants killed before harvest?
options: Ensures the potatoes do not turn green
The skin of the potato sets ie matures
Prevents the tubers shrivelling due to water loss
Prevents viruses from migrating down to the tubers
I dont know and dont want to guess
361090.correct_answer: The skin of the potato sets ie matures
361090.explanation: The correct answer is: The skin of the potato sets i.e. matures. All the time the tops are green, the tubers will be expanding, and the skin of the potato will be stretching. Once the tops are dead the potato skin will mature and seal the potato tuber.

342530.question: What is the most likely cause of the variation in colour seen here in this field of wheat?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
342530.explanation: The correct answer is: Uneven fertiliser distribution The straight line between the stunted yellow crop and the lush green crop indicate that the difference is due to a mechanical effect. The general yellowing of the crop on the left is typical of wheat hungry for nitrogen, whereas the dark green crop on the right appears to have had too much nitrogen and that is exactly what happened. The incorrect answers were: Nematodes attacking the roots; nematodes can cause stunting and yellowing of plants but attack is never uniform as seen here, nor in a straight line. Variation in soil type ; the soil can have a significant effect on crop growth and variation between soils can be dramatic, but they are never in a completely straight line. Viral infection ; Viruses can cause yellowing and stunting as seen here but they do not form lines like this.

357329.question: What is this material on the upper surface of these citrus leaves?
options: Dont know and I dont want to guess
357329.explanation: The correct answer is: Honey dew. There is no sooty mould growing on the honey dew which is why it remains clear (and sticky). Insects in the upper branches have deposited it on the leaves, where it will remain, until rain washes it off.

356998.question: This is the very characteristic symptoms of downy mildew on cucumber.  Which group of pathogens are these symptoms more often associated with?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356998.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus : The symptoms could undoubtedly be described as a mosaic , a symptom often synonymous with viral infection.  Phytoplasmas do not generally create a mosaic , they turn leaves yellow. Nematodes cause a general yellowing of the leaves and not a mosaic . Nutrient deficiencies will often cause a mottle in which the yellow and green areas are not so distinct from each other as seen here.

344546.question: These are nitrogen fixing nodules, but they can be mistaken for nematode galls caused by Meloidogyne species.  What is it about these nodules that indicates they are NOT nematode galls?
options: They are on the side of the root not in the middle
I dont know and dont want to guess
344546.correct_answer: They are on the side of the root not in the middle
344546.explanation: The correct answer is: They are on the side of the root and not in the middle When considering if a lump is a gall or a nodule, one simple rule is: if you can detach it without breaking the root it is a nodule.  Nodules are always displaced to the side of the root, whereas galls usually appear to be part of the root. The incorrect answers were: They are not intensely coloured Both galls and nodules are generally whitish. Galls may be creamy coloured and nodules may have a slight pink colour. They are less than 4mm across Nodules are always less than 4mm across, but galls can vary in size from a few millimetres to up to 15 mm and larger. They are round in cross section. Both galls and nodules are normally round in cross section.

359636.question: A disease of pine trees, how is this symptom best described?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359636.explanation: The correct answer is: Pustule : Most of us are more familiar with pustules on broad leaved plants, but pines get rusts too. This is Rhabdocline needlecast caused by Rhabdocline weirii on Douglas fir.

357332.question: What is this unusual material on this okra leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357332.explanation: The correct answer is: Hyper parasite : This is Ampelomyces quisqualis, a hyper parasite of the powdery mildew . It is a form of biological control .

342529.question: Potatoes are grown from seed potatoes; small tubers that may have begun to sprout.  If the seed potatoes are large, what technique could a gardener or farmer employ?
options: Cut the potatoes in half and plant both halves thereby doubling your numbers of seed potatoes
Plant them as they are do not cut the potatoes the wound would allow opportunistic pathogens in the soil to infect the tuber
Slash the skin of the potato to shock it into growing
Do not plant large seed potatoes as they will not sprout go and buy some smaller ones
Dont know and dont want to guess
342529.correct_answer: Cut the potatoes in half and plant both halves thereby doubling your numbers of seed potatoes
342529.explanation: The correct answer is: Cut the potatoes in half and plant both halves thereby doubling your numbers of seed potatoes. Provided it is dried off before planting, the large wound created when cutting a seed potato does not let in pathogens and is a well-known technique with potato growers (for horticultural reasons, cut them in half lengthways so both halves get the rose and stem ends of the potato). The incorrect answers were: Plant them as they are; do not cut the potatoes, the wound will let in opportunistic pathogens from the soil: they could be planted as they are but cutting them is an option (see above). Slash the skin of the potato to shock it into growing: this is not a recognised technique and does not work. Do not plant large seed potatoes as they will not sprout; go and buy some smaller ones : you may want to consider eating the larger potatoes but they will grow.

359633.question: What is causing the dramatic leaf spot on this ivy leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359633.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungus The spot has a strong border which indicates a fungal pathogen is responsible but, most significantly, there are small black dots littering the spot , these are the fungal fruiting bodies leaving no doubt that the cause is a fungal pathogen .
