340695.question: What is the most likely cause of the yellowing in this field of beans?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
340695.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage: the dramatic bleaching of the upper leaves is a symptom associated with herbicide treatment. The plants on the right appear not to have been treated, note the very sharp line between the healthy plants and those with symptoms. The incorrect answers were: Nematodes: attacking the roots can cause the leaves to turn yellow but usually the whole plant will have this symptom and not just the upper leaves. Nutrient deficiency: is a common cause for plants to turn yellow but compare the plants at the edge of the field which appear to have no symptoms. It is unlikely that there would be this much variation in the soil over such small distances. Viral infection: the symptoms of viral infection are often a mosaic rather than the bleaching seen here and the symptoms would not be restricted to only on a section of the crop (see above).

361083.question: Leaf distortion due to mineral deficiency is very unusual, but the lack of which nutrient is causing distortion in this potato leaf?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
361083.explanation: The correct answer is: Zinc. It is very unusual to see a deficiency in a nutrient causing in leaf distortion, but it does happen occasionally.  Zinc deficiency can be manifest in many different ways depending on the crop.  In this case the leaves of the potato are folded and narrow due to a shortage of zinc however in other crops the symptoms of zinc deficiency are very different

361088.question: During the winter months, when there is no actively growing potato crop, where does Phytophthora infestans survive in the UK?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
361088.explanation: The correct answer is: Potato dumps. In many countries (UK included) there are not both mating types present and so the pathogen cannot make the thick-walled resting spores (oospores) that are commonly produced by Phytophthoras.  The pathogen will survive on volunteer potatoes and on those which have been discarded.

361424.question: Weed control in rhubarb can be difficult, but why is it important not to use glyphosate on a rhubarb crop?
options: The oxalate in the leaves will react with the chemical to produce carcinogens
The red rhubarb stem will turn white and be unsaleable
Rhubarb is extremely sensitive to glyphosate and the slightest exposure will kill it
Weeds which commonly crowd rhubarb have become resistant to glyphosate
Dont know and dont want to guess
361424.correct_answer: Rhubarb is extremely sensitive to glyphosate and the slightest exposure will kill it
361424.explanation: The correct answer is: Rhubarb is extremely sensitive to glyphosate and the slightest exposure will kill it: The sensitivity of rhubarb to glyphosate is remarkable, I know this to my cost.  The slightest bit of drift will kill the rhubarb outright.

364187.question: Dothistroma Needle Blight was previously known as?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364187.explanation: The correct answer is: Red band needle blight Dothistroma needle blight (DNB) is an economically important disease of conifer trees (trees with cones and needles), and particularly pines (trees in the Pinus genus ). It is caused by the fungus Dothistroma septosporum It causes premature needle defoliation, resulting in loss of timber yield and, in severe cases, tree death. It is also known as red band needle blight because of the colourful symptoms it shows on pine trees, as in the picture above.

364184.question: Which virus can produce an oak leaf discolouration pattern on the leaves of Rowan?
options: European mountain ash ringspot associated virus
European mountain ash oakleaf associated virus
European mountain rowan oakleaf associated virus
Dont know and dont want to guess
364184.correct_answer: European mountain ash ringspot associated virus
364184.explanation: The correct answer is: European mountain ash ringspot associated virus The European mountain ash ringspot associated virus (EMARaV) is a pathogen that infects mountain ash trees ( Sorbus aucuparia ). The pathogen attacks the leaves of its hosts where it causes mottling and discoloration. In extreme cases the productivity of the tree can be affected, which can result in its gradual decline. IMAGE: Adrian Fox, Fera Science Ltd.

364669.question: Resistance can develop to any fungicide but what kind of fungicide is resistance most likely to develop
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364669.explanation: The correct answer is: Single site systemic . Fungicides with a single mode of action are more likely to have resistance developed against them as are systemic fungicides.  Multisite contact fungicides like Chlorothalonil or Macozeb have been used for years without resistance developing whereas resistance developed quickly to Azoxystrobin; single site with systemic action.

352206.question: What symptom is this a large example of?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352206.explanation: The correct answer is: Canker : Canker is almost always a symptom of woody tissue , the pathogen attempts to invade the host and the host lays down material to prevent it. This on-going battle leads to a wound with raised edges. The incorrect answers were: Gall : this is an undifferentiated growth of host tissue and does not have this wound aspect to it. Tumour : not a word that is frequently used in plant pathology . Lesion : the symptom could be described as a lesion , but as it is woody with enlarged edges, canker is a better term.

365642.question: Few plant diseases are caused by Actinomycetes, but Common scab caused by Streptomyces scabiei is a good example. 3-6 weeks after tuber initiation is a critical period in the development of this disease. What should be done to control this disease at this stage?
options: Earth up the potatoes to prevent light reaching them
I dont know and I dont want to guess
365642.explanation: The correct answer is: Keep the developing tubers moist. There are few examples where keeping the plant wet will prevent disease , but this is one of them. Crops should be irrigated at this critical period if there is insufficient rainfall to keep the surface of the tuber moist.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

361420.question: Asparagus rust caused by Puccinia asparagi is an autoecious macrocyclic rust fungus.  What does this mean?
options: It is not possible to culture the fungus in the laboratory
Its life cycle requires two unrelated plants
It only infects the male asparagus plants the female plants are immune
It completes its whole lifecycle on asparagus and goes through the full compliment of spore types
I dont know and I dont want to guess
361420.correct_answer: It completes its whole lifecycle on asparagus and goes through the full compliment of spore types
361420.explanation: The correct answer is: It completes its whole lifecycle on asparagus and goes through the full compliment of spore types.  Autoecious  means it has only one host and  macrocyclic  means it has all the spore types seen in rust fungi.  Asparagus does have males and females but both are equally susceptible . As for all rust fungi, it is not possible to culture it in the laboratory.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

356597.question: Sun-scorch (seen here) and paraquat damage look similar: pale papery regions on leaves with very sharp edges.  How can they be differentiated?
options: Sunscorch will develop as yellow regions before the tissue dries
Sunscorch will develop slowly over time
Fruiting bodies may be seen in the sunscorch lesion
I dont know and I dont want to guess
356597.explanation: The correct answer is: Spread pattern on the leaf/plant: Paraquat is a chemical that induces sun-scorch, even at low light intensity. The damage appears the same; the only way of telling them apart is the pattern of damage on the plant. The incorrect answers were: Sun-scorch will develop as yellow regions before the tissue dries: this is not true; the tissue does not yellow before turning brown. Sun-scorch will develop slowly over time: this is not true; the tissue will die immediately. Fruiting bodies may be seen in the sun-scorch lesion ; both sun-scorch and paraquat are abiotic causes and would never have fruiting bodies within the lesion .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365629.question: These symptoms are caused by Alternaria solani and the disease is often referred to as Early blight.   How can the symptoms be distinguished from late blight?
options: Small discrete spots with no yellowing around the necrosis
The spots are on the upper surface of the leaf only
There is no leaf distortion around the infected areas
The symptoms are seen on a mature leaf and not a young leaf
I dont know and I dont want to guess
365629.correct_answer: Small discrete spots with no yellowing around the necrosis
365629.explanation: The correct answer is: Small discrete spots with no yellowing around the necrosis : In this case there is a clear line between the healthy and the diseased tissue , the spots do not appear to be spreading rapidly and there is almost no yellowing. All these symptoms (along with the concentric circles within the spots which cannot be seen here) are indicative of early blight .

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

346544.question: What is the causing the pattern on this parsnip leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
346544.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus infection This is the symptom of the, aptly named, parsnip yellow fleck virus . It is an aphid transmitted virus but cannot spread between parsnip plants. The aphid can only transmit the virus if there is an additional helper virus present, but the helper virus cannot survive in the parsnip. All infections are due to aphids migrating in from wild relatives (in which, both the helper and yellow fleck virus can survive). The incorrect answers were: Insect feeding Sap-feeding insects (aphids, mealybug, scale etc.,) dont usually make much of a mark on leaves. There are exceptions, but usually they produce necrosis and not yellowing. Bacterial infection Bacteria can cause yellowing, but not in a mosaic pattern such as this. Nutrient deficiency Yellow and green regions on the same leaf can be typical of some nutrient deficiencies, but the transition between the green and yellow is usually blurred and they are not intermingled as seen here.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

365342.question: The stripes on this maize is due to what may be considered an unusual cause.  What has caused these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
365342.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew . Very few grasses are hosts to the downy mildews.  An exception is maize and here you see the stripes of green and yellow typical of this disease on this host.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)

359221.question: This larva was found eating the roots of a lettuce plant. What will the adult form be?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359221.explanation: The correct answer is: Moth: The large head capsule , the three pairs of prolegs and the four pairs of little stubby legs all show that, despite its subterranean lifestyle, it is caterpillar and will turn into a moth. This is a Cutworm, they get their name due to their habit of feeding on the base of the plants and often, in the case of a small seedling, they will chew right through it.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357002.question: These tiny leaves growing from this bramble is the typical regrowth following glyphosate application.  Which group of pathogens or pest are these symptoms more typical of?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357002.explanation: The correct answer is: Phytoplasma infection: Tiny leaves little leaves are often a symptom of phytoplasma infection. Aphids can distort leaves and it is also a common symptom of viral infection but generally neither induce the extreme reduction in size seen here.

362989.question: Potato plants at RHS Wisley
362989.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Im not sure if this is late blight or not. But its definitely biotic . The necrotic lesions have a defined border, unlike the more diffuse and spreading areas I associate with Phytophthora infestans . A colleague who worked with potatoes and helped to run a diagnostic lab in Scotland said that they often put leaves into a sealed bag overnight to see if the suspect late blight symptoms developed a furry surface.

356993.question: This symptom in radish is extremely characteristic, the symptoms are caused by downy mildew.  Based on first principles what would you generally have thought would have caused these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356993.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection: As stated in the question downy mildew has caused the symptoms but fungal infection, would be the most obvious of the potential other causes.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355515.question: What has caused these marks on this potato leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
355515.explanation: The correct answer is: Micro-browsing insects. The contents of the surface cells of the leaf have been sucked out.  Pests that commonly do this are thrips and mites, but, in this case, it was leaf hoppers that did the damage. The incorrect answers were: Powdery mildew ; this common fungal pathogen rarely attacks potatoes. It is not the cause here. Phytophthora ; late blight is very common on potato crops, but the symptoms are not like this.  Rapidly expanding black zones, with a pale perimeter are the typical symptoms. Virus ; speckle such as this can be mistaken for a viral mosaic but, look carefully at the photo, this is not a mosaic , there are no panels of yellow and green.

360090.question: What is the milky white substance drifting from the cut stem of a wilted aubergine (brinjal) plant?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360090.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria: This is the bacterial streaming test.  In some cases of bacterial wilt , it is possible to see the millions of bacteria oozing from the cut end of a stem. This is one of the few occasions it is possible to actually see plant pathogenic bacteria.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352213.question: What is the best term to describe this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352213.explanation: The correct answer is: Mosaic : This term is often used to describe virally infected plants, but all viral infections do not lead to mosaic symptoms and not all mosaics are due to viral infection. Note that this leaf is also rugose. The incorrect answers were: Yellowed : some of the leaf is undoubtedly yellow, but it is the relationship between the yellow and green areas that are important. Variegated : the leaf is variegated, and this is not wrong, but mosaic is the usual term used when describing viral symptoms. Blotchy : it could be described as blotchy, but this term is not often used in plant pathology .

361414.question: What has caused the ghostly patterns on this rhubarb leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
361414.explanation: The correct answer is: Viral infection The symptoms seen here are due to Tobacco streak virus . It has a wide host range and produces a variety of symptoms including tissue necrosis on some hosts.  It can be spread by both seed and, most unusually, pollen in some hosts. The insect vectors are thrips.

364673.question: Oomycetes (watermoulds) look like fungi and are often considered as fungi (Phytophthora and the downy mildew pathogens).  To what extent do chemicals sold as fungicides control these oomycete diseases?
options: Some oomycetes can be controlled by some fungicides
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364673.explanation: The correct answer is: Some fungicides will control oomycetes: Oomycides or watermouldicides dont often enter into our language. People talk of fungicides controlling the oomycetes, however although many fungicides have activity against oomycetes many do not (Metalaxyl as a good example).

363382.question: Unless you have seen this previously it is unlikely anyone would get this question correct. It is not viral infection causing this leaf distortion but what is it?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
363382.explanation: The correct answer is: Mineral deficiency Leaf distortion due to mineral deficiency is rare, even more so when that mineral is zinc. This is zinc deficiency in potato.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

349785.question: These galls on grapevine are due to Grape phylloxera; an aphid-like insect that has both root and leaf feeding phases in the lifecycle. It is an extremely unusual symptom for this group of insects.  Leaf galls such as these are much more often associated with group?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
349785.explanation: The correct answer is: Mites: Galls on leaves such as those seen here are commonly produced by eriophyid mites. Incorrect answers were: Whitefly: small white flies producing plenty of white wax are the symptoms of whitefly, not galls. Leaf miners: there is no leaf-mining group of insects as such; several different species of insect have adopted this habitat . Long, silvery, winding trails through the leaf are the symptoms and typically not galls. Mealy bugs:  white slow-moving waxy insects hiding in crevices, is how they are often described, and they are not associated with gall production.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350681.question: Many agrochemical inputs are extremely toxic to humans and the environment.  Which of these statements is generally true?
options: Fungicides are generally more toxic than insecticides
Insecticides are generally more toxic than fungicides
The toxicity of both fungicides and insecticides is about the same
It is the formulation of the active ingredient that affects its toxicity and not the product itself
Dont know and dont want to guess
350681.correct_answer: Insecticides are generally more toxic than fungicides
350681.explanation: The correct answer is: Insecticides are generally more toxic than fungicides: Fungicides are toxic but their toxicity is generally much less than that of the insecticides. The incorrect answers were: Fungicides are generally more toxic than insecticides: the reverse is true. The toxicity of both fungicides and insecticides is about the same : this is not the case. It is the formulation of the active ingredient that affects its toxicity and not the product itself : the formulation of product does not affect the toxicity of the active ingredient but it may affect your exposure to the chemical.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

349782.question: What is the best description of this symptom?
options: I dont know and I dont want guess
349782.explanation: The correct answer is: Ringspots: The spot on the leaf has a green centre, thus the spot is a ring.  This symptom is almost always due to viral infection and, more often than not, vectored by a nematode . The incorrect answers were: Frass: frass is a term for excrement (usually applied to that of insects but not exclusively). Mosaic : a mosaic as a symptom literally looks like a mosaic , with hard, angular edges to the blocks of colour.  Mosaics are almost always yellow and green. Spots: the definition of a spot on a leaf is a tricky one and there are lots of definitions.  This clearly is a spot BUT ringspot is a far better answer.

360094.question: This is grey mould (Botrytis cinerea) on courgette. Whilst the dusty grey sporulation is clearly visible why are there no small black fungal fruiting bodies that are commonly seen in fungal infections?
options: Botrytis does not sporulate in that way
The infection is not old enough and they will be produced later
The conditions were not right for the production of flask shaped fruiting bodies
The grey sporulation suppressed their production
Dont know and dont want to guess
360094.correct_answer: Botrytis does not sporulate in that way
360094.explanation: The correct answer is: Botrytis does not sporulate in that way: Whilst the observation of small black fruiting bodies within a lesion can confirm the identity of the pathogen as a fungus there are also many fungi do not produce them. Botrytis can produce sclerotia (see question 2) from which the small fruiting bodies subsequently grow but they are generally not seen embedded in the host tissue .

359641.question: Sprouts are often eaten as part of a traditional Christmas lunch, but what is on the surface of these sprout leaves?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359641.explanation: The correct answer is: Ice crystals: Frost has come down and coated these leaves with a wonderfully delicate array of crystals.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357980.question: How many pathogens on this wheat leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357980.explanation: The correct answer is: Two pathogens Two pathogens on the leaf.  The orangey rust pustules are embedded within the leaf whereas the white powdery mildew is growing over the surface.  Notice that neither pathogen is causing a significant visible host reaction.

361417.question: What are these?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
361417.explanation: The correct answer is: Insect eggs: These are the eggs of the asparagus beetle, Crioceris asparagi, potentially a serious pest of asparagus.

352207.question: In this case, the floral parts of the sesame plant have not developed and have emerged as leaves (left and right plants).  What is the technical name of this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352207.explanation: The correct answer is: Phyllody : Not a common symptom (except in sesame): phyllody is the production of leaves in place of petals.  Phytoplasmas, and occasionally viruses, can induce this symptom . The incorrect answers were: Witches broom: it could be considered to be a type of witches broom, but, as the leaves are replacing the petals and other floral parts, it is phyllody . Proliferation: there is considerable proliferation at the top of the plant, but that is a general term for excessive growth. Fasciation: there is no evidence of fasciation here.

363136.question: This is downy mildew of radish.  A very unusual symptom of a downy mildew.  What would be a reasonable diagnosis if you were unaware of this disease?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363136.explanation: The correct answer is: All correct Not meaning to trick you but any of the answers could have caused this internal necrosis .  This is the only example of a downy mildew attacking below ground that I am aware of.

362714.question: Detached shoots of oregano; contrast the different growth forms. Both forms appear in the same plants.
362714.explanation: The correct answer is Confused. Without further information  did the farmer spray glyphosate, for example; or the results of lab tests  its difficult to be certain whats going on here. But its strange enough to warrant further investigation. These revealed a close association between phytoplasma and the altered growth form.

364430.question: What is the common name of this long horn beetle that could threaten the supply of plum pudding?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
364430.explanation: Answer: Red necked beetle ( Aromia bungii ) is native to eastern Asia and poses a serious threat to a range of fruit and ornamental Prunus , as well as other hardwood trees. The larvae feed and tunnel under the bark and in the wood of both healthy and stressed trees and can affect fruit yield. Trees may be weakened or even killed after several successive years of infestation by this insect pest . The climate in much of the UK would be conducive to the establishment and spread of red-necked longhorn beetle, whose main pathway of entry to this country is via the live plant trade and in wood packaging material.

360086.question: What are these black dots on the surface of this powdery mildew?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360086.explanation: The correct answer is: Cleistothecia These small black dots are occasionally seen in the white powdery mass that is typical of powdery mildew .  The numbers seen here are exceptional.  The cleistothecia are the sexual stage of the fungus which hold many hundreds of ascospores within.  The cleistothecia are resistant to desiccation and can be considered the resting stage of this fungus.

363761.question: This is white rust on Salsify, this group are not true rusts (nor are they true fungi) they are oomycetes.   Is it possible to grow this group of pathogens in culture?
options: Yes they will grow on regular media
Cannot grow away from a host plant
Can be grown on media provided an extract of a host plant is included as an ingredient
Can be grown in culture but growth is extremely slow
I dont know and I dont want to guess
363761.correct_answer: Cannot grow away from a host plant
363761.explanation: The correct answer is: Cannot grow away from a host plant . The white rusts are not related to true rusts in any way, but they do have similar characteristics such as requiring a host plant to grow on.

346546.question: How does petal fall influence the decision to spray a fungicide?
options: Once the petals have fallen the developing fruit is extremely exposed to pathogen attack
Petals add nutrients to the leaf surface and can assist infection by opportunistic pathogens
Petal fall is a good midpoint in the growth of a plant to put on a spray
The fall of petals has no bearing on fungicide application
Dont know and dont want to guess
346546.correct_answer: Petals add nutrients to the leaf surface and can assist infection by opportunistic pathogens
346546.explanation: The correct answer is: Petals add nutrients to the leaf surface and can assist infection by opportunistic pathogens. The leaf surface can be a hostile environment for fungal pathogens, but the additional nutrients provided by the petals can provide a stimulus to allow infection. The incorrect answers were: Once the petals have fallen, the developing fruit is extremely exposed to pathogen attack. This may occur to some extent, but the presence of the petals does not really protect the ovaries. Petal fall is a good mid-point in the growth of a plant to put on a spray. This may be the case, but crop protection should not be about calendar spraying. The fall of petals has no bearing on fungicide application. This is not the case, see above.

342527.question: What is the correct term for these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
342527.explanation: The correct answer is: Mosaic The incorrect answers were: Mottle: the sharp lines between the yellow are green areas on the leaf make this a mosaic . If they were blurred and the contrast in colour was not so great, it may be considered a mottle. Yellowed : this is a term used to describe a leaf where the whole leaf has lost its green colour. Speckled :  this is a symptom that can look similar to a mosaic but the effect is due to the empty surface cells reflecting light (empty due to feeding of a mite or thrips) and the leaf has not changed colour beneath.

352212.question: What is the most accurate technical name for these distorted leaves?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
352212.explanation: The correct answer is: Rugose: The leaves are clearly distorted but not thickened into true blisters and the leaf is its normal thickness.  It is a very common kind of leaf distortion often called blistering but this is actually incorrect. The incorrect answers were : Blistered: the leaves have not swollen into blisters. Crinkled : not a word that is used in plant pathology . Shrinkled: a word that is sometimes used in some countries but is not an official word.

358238.question: What has caused this extreme proliferation of these sugarbeet roots?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
358238.explanation: The correct answer is: Virus : Beet necrotic yellow vein virus This is a disease called Rhizomania, extremely unusual symptoms for a virus ; it is transmitted by the soil-borne fungus Polymyxa betae . Foliar symptoms show various degrees of stunting , wilting, and yellowing and often may be confused with a nutritional deficiency.

350675.question: Which of these features indicates that this is sun scorch damage:  Severe transition from healthy to dead tissue:  Light tan paper colour of dead region: Lack of any structure to the dead zone: No areas have mild symptoms
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
350675.explanation: The correct answer is: All four: The symptoms of sun scorch are seen in this photo.  There is always a severe transition between the healthy and dead tissue .  Other abiotic factors can do this such as fertilizer scorch and damage from some herbicides.

358235.question: What is the cause of this necrosis in the centre of this potato?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
358235.explanation: The correct answer is: Physiological condition; no pathogen involved This is black heart or hollow heart of potato. There are no external symptoms. It can develop in the field or in storage. This physiological condition is associated with low oxygen levels.

364664.question: Classifying fungicides into resistance categories is relevant to whom?
options: Mycologists and molecular biologists who study fungi
Those working in agrochemical research and product
Research workers who work in field stations and do field trials
All those who make recommend or use fungicides
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364664.correct_answer: All those who make recommend or use fungicides
364664.explanation: The correct answer is: All those who make, recommend, or use fungicides. It is essential that all those working with fungicides under the concept of resistance and which resistance group various fungi are in.

359220.question: What is the cause of these leafspots?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359220.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungus Any of the suggested answers can cause leafspots, but there are various clues to point to this being a fungal pathogen : the spots are all of a similar size, they are not associated with the edge of the leaf or with damage and they are discreet and not spreading up or down the leaf veins. All of these features indicate (but do not prove) the pathogen is a fungus. This is Cercospora lactucae-sativae (cercospora leaf spot of lettuce).

364418.question: Poinsettias are a very popular Christmas plant. However, they rely on a plant pathogen for their appeal. What feature of these poinsettias is due to a phytoplasma infection?
options: Symptomless phytoplasma infection prevents infection from other diseases
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364418.explanation: Answer: The short stem height. Wild poinsettias are tall plants well over 1.5m tall. It is infection by a phytoplasma that ensures the dwarf habit and makes them ideal pot plants.

363753.question: Rust fungi are very common pathogens, but can they be grown in culture?
options: Special media is required but they can be cultured
Yes many kinds of media will support the growth of rusts
Not possible to grow on agar but can be grown in liquid media
No they cannot be cultured externally to a host plant
Dont know and dont want to guess
363753.correct_answer: No they cannot be cultured externally to a host plant
363753.explanation: The correct answer is: No they cannot be cultured externally to a host plant . There are no media that can support the growth of rust fungi.

357001.question: What appears to be a rot in these cassava tubers is induced by Cassava Brown streak mosaic virus extremely unusual symptoms of a viral pathogen.  What would be more likely to have produced these symptoms?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357001.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial pathogen : Unless you had prior knowledge of this complaint it would reasonable to suggest that these symptoms were induced by a bacterial (or fungal) pathogen . Nematodes can cause this type of damage to roots but will always do so from the outside of the root and work inwards. Mineral deficiency can cause internal tissue breakdown generally it more extensive than that seen here. Phytoplasmas do not cause these symptoms.

363370.question: This should be an easy one for anyone who has grown potatoes;  a worldwide problem but what is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363370.explanation: The correct answer is: Late blight (Phytophthora infestans) The classic necrosis surrounded by the white bloom of sporulation is clear in this photo. Powdery mildew is extremely rare on potatoes and is not typical of powdery mildews when it does occur and there is no downy mildew of potato (although Phytophthora is a close relative).

360481.question: What is attacking this dahlia flower?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
360481.explanation: The correct answer is: Botrytis cinerea: This opportunist pathogen is extremely common and attacks weakened tissue flowers and fruits.  It causes Grey mould and the grey sporulation can be seen on top of the rotting bud.

346545.question: What it the cause of this necrotic area on this water melon?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
346545.explanation: The correct answer is: Nutrient deficiency This is one symptom that you cannot get from using first principals of plant pathology . It is often seen on rapidly growing fruits, especially tomatoes and cucurbits. When growing rapidly, the plant cannot mobilise calcium to the expanding tissue fast enough and it begins to break down. This is only ever seen at the blossom end of the fruit, hence the name blossom end rot . The incorrect answers were: Sun scald This can affect fruits and can look similar, but would be on the top of the fruit and not on the end. Bacterial infection This would be a very reasonable suggestion if the rot was not at the blossom end. Fungal infection This would be a very reasonable suggestion if the rot was not at the blossom end.

344548.question: The uppermost leaf of a cereal crop is often referred to as the flag leaf.  In the photo you can see the ear emerging, the leaf above it is flag leaf.  What is the importance of the flag leaf in wheat?
options: The flag leaf is unimportant as the ear has already formed by the time it emerges
The flag leaf will shade the ear and actually reduces yield
It is just as important as any other leaf
It is extremely important as it provides the sugars to fill the grain
I dont know and dont want to guess
344548.correct_answer: It is extremely important as it provides the sugars to fill the grain
344548.explanation: The correct answer is: It is extremely important as it provides the sugars to fill the grain In wheat, the flag leaf is the most important one to keep free of diseases. If only one fungicide spray is applied to a wheat crop, it is best to do it when the flag leaf has just emerged. This is not the case in other cereals where the flag leaf may play a relatively minor role (e.g. barley). The incorrect answers were: The flag leaf is unimportant as the ear has already formed by the time it emerges. It is true that the ear has formed but there is no grain in the ear. The flag leaf will shade the ear and actually reduces yield. The ear itself does contribute to grain fill to an extent and there will be some shading, but that is insignificant and you want the flag leaf to be in full sun. It is just as important as any other leaf. With regard to grain fill, the importance of the leaves falls off rapidly as you descend the plant.

346539.question: This is a leaf from a globe artichoke plant, a crop commonly grown in the Mediterranean and South America.  What is the most likely cause of the lesion on the side of the leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
346539.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial infection There is not a great deal of information here, but the one leaf lesion we can see is: spreading from the edge of the leaf, does not have a clearly defined border and there is no structure to the lesion . All of these factors suggest that the cause is bacterial. The incorrect answers were: Fungal infection It is possible that this could be a fungal infection, but appears more like a bacterial one. Nutrient deficiency Necrotic leaf spots such as this are not typical of nutrient deficiencies. Water mould infection There are very few water moulds that commonly attack the leaves of these plants, so this would be unlikely .

359640.question: Cranberry is often eaten as part of a traditional Christmas meal, with turkey, but what has happened to this cranberry leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
359640.explanation: The correct answer is: Slime Mould : This is Diderma simplex, a slime mould : one of those fungi that are almost not fungi and are extremely atypical of this biological Kingdom . It is said that there are no plant pathogenic slime moulds.  I will let you do the research to find out if this is true.

364188.question: Acute oak decline is an emerging disease of oak trees  characterised by a distinctive set of externally visible stem symptoms.  This includes which symptoms?
options: Bark cracks which weep dark exudates
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364188.explanation: The correct answer is: All the above AOD typically affects older oak trees, but it has also been found in younger trees. It causes dark bleeds down the trunk of the tree. You may find the small, D-shaped exit holes of the oak jewel beetle in the bark. In severe cases the tree starts to lose leaves, causing the crown to thin. AOD can be fatal within 4 to 6 years of the symptoms first appearing.

365620.question: This is the symptom of tobacco rattle virus on a peeled potato.  Viruses are a common pathogen of potato; what can be done to remove a virus from a potato that you are about to plant?
options: Dip in hot water for a specific amount of time
Wash the potatoes in dilute bleach
None of the above will work
Dont know and dont want to guess
365620.correct_answer: None of the above will work
365620.explanation: The correct answer is: None of the above will work. Once a tuber is infected with a virus it is not possible to rid the potato tuber of the virus ; a virus infected plant will develop. Note; it is unusual to see symptoms of a virus in the tubers.

351962.question: If a country already has a pathogen well established in its agricultural systems why it is still important, in some cases, to prevent new strains arriving?
options: To prevent the sexual cycle of the pathogen proceeding
It is good to keep the amount of pathogen low in whatever way you can
It will allow imports to be excluded so that local farmers can be supported
The identification of the pathogen may not have been accurate and another pathogen may gain access
I dont know and dont want to guess
351962.correct_answer: To prevent the sexual cycle of the pathogen proceeding
351962.explanation: The correct answer is: To prevent the sexual cycle of the pathogen proceeding: This photo is of oospores; they are sexual spores of the oomycetes (water moulds). In some pathogens (such as P.infestans which causes late blight of potato or tomato) oospores will only form if there are   and  strains present. Many countries only have one of the two mating types , thus preventing sexual spores being produced. The incorrect answers were: It is good to keep the amount of pathogen low in whatever way you can; whilst this is true, the amount of additional pathogen arriving on imports would be miniscule relative to the established population. It will allow imports to be excluded so that local farmers can be supported; under WTO rules it is not easy to exclude produce except for phytosanitary reasons, but this is not the reason from a plant pathology viewpoint. The identification of the pathogen may not have been accurate and another pathogen may gain access to the country; this is unlikely as phytosanitary inspectors are well trained and are supported by expert scientists who test potential new pathogens found on imported material.

348211.question: Which of these leaves is showing typical symptoms of late blight as caused by Phytophthora infestans?
348211.explanation: The correct answer is: A The necrotic region with very little yellowing is typical of late blight on tomato. The white bloom of sporulation is seen around the edge of the necrotic area. (Spreading of necrosis into the leaf, with a band of sporulation bordering it, is extremely characteristic of late blight infection). The incorrect answers were: B This mottling is more typical of a mineral deficiency; possibly manganese deficiency in this case. C The tips of the leaves have become necrotic, but there is no sign of any sporulation. D The yellowing around the necrotic regions is not typical of late blight . E The tan necrotic regions are not typical of late blight under normal conditions.

363763.question: This a young banana plant badly damaged by nematode attack.  Can plant parasitic nematodes be grown in culture?
options: Yes they will thrive on regular microbial media
Yes but they require root extracts to be present in the medium
If after antibiotic application they can be rendered sterile they can be cultured
Dont know and dont want to guess
363763.explanation: The correct answer is: They cannot be cultured. Nematodes are found in a great number of environments, but the plant parasitic nematodes do not grow without the presence of a living plant

364661.question: There are relatively few fungal pathogens of humans but they are on the rise. How is resistance to fungicides in human medicine related to agricultural fungicide use?
options: They are entirely separate fungal species and resistance in human pathogens is unrelated to agricultural use
Fungicide resistance in plant pathogens is directly relevant to the control of human pathogens
There are examples of fungicide resistance spreading from medicine into crop pathogens
There are some examples of resistance spreading from agriculture into medically important pathogens
Dont know and dont want to guess
364661.correct_answer: There are some examples of resistance spreading from agriculture into medically important pathogens
364661.explanation: The correct answer is: There are some examples of resistance spreading from agriculture into medically important pathogens. Resistance to the triazole group of fungicides has spread from agriculture to human pathogens.

355516.question: Upper and lower surface of peach leaves.  What is the cause of the red colouration?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
355516.explanation: The correct answer is: Powdery mildew : It is unusual for powdery mildew to cause anything other than a white dusty growth over the upper surface of a leaf, but here there is considerable host reaction and the sporulation is on the lower surface. The incorrect answers were: Viral infection; viral ringspots are unusual but can look like this; if you missed the white powdery growth on the leaf at the top of the photo viral infection was a good answer. Unidentified fungal infection; There are fungi that induce considerable reddening of the host (blackberry rust is a good example), but it is unusual AND you could have spotted the sporulation on the underside of the leaf. Bacterial infection ; infection by a bacterial pathogen does not generally cause anything other than tissue death.

360484.question: Leaf edge necrosis seen here on cocoa is a classic symptom indicating a deficiency of which nutrient?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360484.explanation: The correct answer is: Potassium (K): There are many things which can cause the edge of leaves to become necrotic, but in this case, it is due to a shortage of potassium within the plant.

363762.question: This is the stroma of Plasmodiophora brassiacae the causal agent of club root of brassicas.  Originally considered a fungus it lacks hyphal type growth and is actually a protist.  Can it be grown in culture?
options: Yes provided the medium contains brassica extract
No it cannot be grown in culture
Will grow in culture but not with a normal fungal type morphology
It can be grown on specialist media with exacting conditions
I dont know and I dont want to guess
363762.correct_answer: No it cannot be grown in culture
363762.explanation: The correct answer is: Not it cannot be grown in culture. It is not possible to culture this protist on artificial medium.

342509.question: Another abiotic factor is the problem on this bean leaf. What do you think has caused the characteristic stipples (red marks) and flecking (larger brown-yellow marks)? What is the most likely cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
342509.explanation: The correct answer is: Ozone Ozone is an under-appreciated threat to agriculture, especially in polluted areas. The symptoms are generally seen on older leaves and beans are particularly susceptible . (Photo; UKCEH) The incorrect answers were: Water logging; roots immersed in water for prolonged periods will damage many crop plants. The symptoms are usually yellowing and wilting . Hydrogen sulphide; can be a problem in rice crops but not usually elsewhere. Excessive humidity; this is one of the causes that can lead to oedema and not the reddening and flecking seen here.

363133.question: This is a photo of downy mildew of cucumber caused by Pseudoperonospora cubensis.  However, if you were not familiar with this disease what could the symptoms be mistaken for?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363133.explanation: The correct answer is: Downy mildew on cucumber looks like a typical viral mosaic The mosaic caused by cucumber downy mildew is a very convincing mosaic and is often thought to be caused by a virus .

363378.question: Which pathogen often causes asymmetric symptoms on potato leaves as seen in the photo?  Note how one half of the leaf is relatively healthy.
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363378.explanation: The correct answer is: Verticillium The early symptoms of Verticillium dahliae infection are characterized by unilateral leaf yellowing. A wilt may develop but the leaves become necrotic as the disease progresses.

349791.question: This is a knapsack sprayer with a hooded shroud over the nozzle. The hood is used to reduce drift as the spray fan is enclosed within the hood.  When should such a shroud be used?
options: Spraying around seedlings when applying herbicide
Dont know and dont want to guess
349791.correct_answer: Spraying around seedlings when applying herbicide
349791.explanation: The correct answer is: Spraying around seedlings when applying herbicide : The shroud prevents drift which theoretically makes it possible to spray round seedlings, however it is extremely easy to kill the seedlings by doing this (as I know to my cost).  As it takes several days for the seedlings and the weeds to die, you dont know you have killed the crop until several days later. The incorrect answers were: Spraying insecticides: it may be appropriate to use a shroud but it would be unusual to do so. Spraying especially toxic chemicals: the shroud is not considered part of personal protective equipment.  You should protect yourself from all agrochemicals when spraying using appropriate PPE. Spraying fungicides: it may be appropriate to use a shroud but it would be unusual to do so.

366384.question: Pre-border  intelligence Q2 The UK Plant Health Risk Register is a useful screening tool for assessing the threat pests and diseases pose, both before and after mitigation measures are put in place.  Using the tool (link below), what is the unmitigated UK Relative Risk Rating posed by the Emerald Ash Borer Agrilus planipennis? UK Plant Health Risk Register
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
366384.explanation: Correct answer : 125 This is the highest possible score for risk. With mitigation the score drops to 75, which is still very high. Agrilus planipennis represents one of the most significant plant health threats to the UK, with the likelihood of an outbreak increasing as the beetle spreads across mainland Europe. The UK governments 2023 National Risk Register (p. 175) includes possible scenarios, along with proposed responses. 2023_NATIONAL_RISK_REGISTER_NRR.pdf (publishing.service.gov.uk) EPPO entry for Emerald Ash Borer: https://gd.eppo.int/taxon/AGRLPL/datasheet

359637.question: This is the adult phase of the white pine weevil on a spruce branch. What specifically is the correct name for its juvenile form?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359637.explanation: The correct answer is: Grub Larva describes all forms of juvenile insect which are yet to undergo metamorphosis. A pupa describes the transition phase, for some insects, between larva and adult. Maggot is a term used to describe the larva of true flies. Beetle juvenile forms, including weevils, can often be described as grubs. Worm is more commonly used in biological terms for invertebrate animals including e.g., the annelids (earthworms, etc), nematodes (roundworms), and flatworms, with slender elongated, legless bodies. Common names often add to the complexity e.g., t he Silkworm is a juvenile moth and the Wireworm a juvenile beetle.

360479.explanation: The correct answer is: Manganese: It isnt really possible to tell which nutrient is lacking here (could have been several), but hopefully you were able to dismiss all the other options.

360088.explanation: The correct answer is: Pileus: There are lots of mycological terms which often do not help in a field diagnosis , but if you want to impress your friends you could refer to the cap of the toadstool as the pileus.

348214.question: Phosphate deficiency can often cause plants to turn red. Why is it clear that this plant is not suffering from phosphate deficiency?
options: The leaves are the wrong shade of red
The upper leaves are red but the lower leaves remained green
Maize is the exception and does not turn red in response to deficiency
I dont know and I dont want to guess
348214.correct_answer: The upper leaves are red but the lower leaves remained green
348214.explanation: The correct answer is: The upper leaves are red, but the lower leaves remained green. The symptoms of phosphate deficiency, like the other major nutrients (nitrogen and potassium), are always seen in the lower leaves first. This reddening is due to stress; caused by a stem borer living in the stem at the point where the plant turns red.  Note that the other plants around are not showing any reddening. The incorrect answers were: The leaves are the wrong shade of red. The red colour develops due to stress and the diagnosis on the hue of the colour is not really possible. The plant is not stunted. Phosphate deficiency does usually stunt plants but not always. Maize is the exception and does not turn red in response to phosphate deficiency. This is not true.

356592.question: Which of the major plant nutrients is found in wood ash?
options: Sulphur often not considered to be a major nutrient
Dont know and dont want to guess
356592.explanation: The correct answer is: Potassium: Wood ash is a good source of potassium salts. The incorrect answers were: There may be trace amounts of the other nutrients but potassium is by far the most abundant.

360475.question: What is causing the mosaic on this rose leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360475.explanation: The correct answer is: Rust infection Mosaics such as this are frequently associated with viral infection, but that is not always the case.  Looking at the upper surface, the go to diagnosis would be virus , but inspecting the lower side reveals the orange pustules which shows the true cause of the mosaic .  Another really common mosaic , not due to a viral infection, is cucumber downy mildew .

355511.question: The symptoms of a deficiency in the major nutrients required for crop cultivation (NPK) all share one thing in common; what is it?
options: Symptoms are seen in the lower leaves first
The very tip of the plant is the first to show symptoms
Symptoms are seen in the young leaves first
I dont know and dont want to guess
355511.correct_answer: Symptoms are seen in the lower leaves first
355511.explanation: The correct answer is: Symptoms are seen in the lower leaves first: Nitrogen, Phosphate and Potassium deficiencies have different symptoms, but share the common factor that it is the lower leaves where symptoms are first seen. The incorrect answers were: The leaves turn yellow; the lower leaves turning yellow is the major indication that the plant is short of nitrogen, but that is not true of the other phosphate or potassium shortage. The very tip of the plant is the first to show symptoms; few nutrition deficiencies are initially seen in the tip of the plant. Symptoms due to calcium and boron are seen here . Symptoms are seen in the young leaves first; a deficiency of almost all of the minor nutrients symptoms are seen in the young leaves first.

340698.question: What is the material on this maize leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340698.explanation: The correct answer is: Pollen: In grasses a lot of pollen is shed and may be seen as a fine dusting on leaves.  The pollen is not a problem in itself, but it will increase the nutrients on the leaf surface which can increase infection by pathogens. This is not so much a problem in broadleaved crops, but the nutrition on the leaf surface can be affected by falling petals. The falling petals may create an environment in which the pathogen can thrive.  In this picture, the additional nutrients from the fallen flower have allowed the pathogen to attack the leaf and start an infection. The incorrect answers were: Frass: can appear in many different forms but is never dry and dusty like this. Sooty mould: is commonly seen on the leaf surface growing on honeydew but is always black. Powdery mildew : is commonly seen growing on leaf surfaces but it cannot be shaken (or blown) from the leaf and is always white.  However, it is not possible to tell that the pollen could be blown from the leaf in this photo.

365626.question: PVX is a virus of potato that is common but often not extremely damaging.  Under what circumstances can it be very damaging?  Photo shows PVX particles as viewed under a scanning electron microscope.
options: When the plant is also infected with a fungal disease
When the plant is lacking nitrogen fertilizer
Dont know and dont want to guess
365626.explanation: The correct answer is: When co-infected with another virus All of the stresses mentioned will not help the situation but when PVX is part of a viral complex infecting the plant, the symptoms are often much more severe than either virus in isolation.

364189.question: What plant disease is vectored by insects from the Cicadellidae and Ceropidae families which include the common froghopper?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
364189.explanation: The correct answer is: Xylella fastidiosa Xylella is a plant disease which can affect several species of broadleaved trees widely grown in the UK, such as oak, elm and plane, as well as a wide range of other commercially grown plants. Among them are grape, citrus, coffee, olive, almond and blueberry species, and many herbaceous plant species. In nature, the bacteria are exclusively transmitted by insects from the Cicadellidae and Ceropidae families, which feed on plants xylem fluid. There are several species of insects in the UK which could act as vectors (agents of spread) of X. fastidiosa bacteria, including the common froghopper ( Philaenus spumarius ). Although such insects usually only fly short distances of up to 100 metres, they can be carried much longer distances by the wind. IMAGE: David Cappaert, Bugwood.org

352205.question: Small leaflets developing on the surface of a leaf can be a sign of pathogen infection, what is the name of this symptom?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
352205.explanation: The correct answer is: Enations : A seldom seen symptom , but it is characteristic of some diseases. The incorrect answers were: Galls: this term usually applies to undifferentiated growth on the surface of a plant. Phyllody : this term may be coming up later in the quiz. 354525.question: Roadside young ash tree in Littondale, Yorkshire. What is the cause of the corky outgrowths?
354525.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial disease . Pseudomonas savastanoi pv. fraxini . Comments on the other options: Genetic abnormality might appear an attractive option yet these are distinctive symptoms with a scattered appearance, more indicative of a precise cause. Insects and mites are common gall -formers on leaves and fleshy tissue  not on woody stems. Yes, there is a fungal canker on ash ( Neonectria ditissima ), which kills tissue rather than stimulating new growth, as seen here. P. savastanoi is an unusual and relatively unknown pathogen , yet widespread and damaging on olive trees (related to ash).

346542.question: Two weeds in a lettuce crop are both infected with downy mildew; both the sow thistle (white highlighted area on left) and the fat hen (black highlighted area on right) have downy mildew. What threat do either of these pose to the lettuce crop?
options: Neither pathogen will spread to the crop
Both pathogens could spread to the crop
The downy mildew on the sow thistle could spread to the crop
The downy mildew on the fat hen could spread to the crop
I dont know and I dont want to guess
346542.correct_answer: The downy mildew on the sow thistle could spread to the crop
346542.explanation: The correct answer is: The downy mildew on the sow thistle could spread to the crop The downy mildews are often very specific in the plants they can attack, but as the sow thistle and lettuce are related, both are susceptible to the same pathogen . Bremia lactucae causes downy mildew on both plants. This is a good example of diseases spreading from weeds. The incorrect answers were: Neither pathogen will spread to the crop see above Both pathogens could spread to the crop see above The downy mildew on the sow thistle could spread to the crop see above The downy mildew on the fat hen could spread to the crop see above

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340692.question: The small black dots within these leaf spots (ringed) clearly indicate the cause; what is the cause of the leaf spots?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340692.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal pathogen : This is brown leaf spot of cassava caused by a fungus. The small black dots seen in the leaf spot are the actual fungus. If the dots are present then fungus is definitely the cause. However, some fungi do not produce black dots, so if the dots are absent then a fungus may still be the cause. The incorrect answers were: Bacterial pathogens: commonly cause leaf spots such as this but they never produce structures that can be seen (even with a hand lens). Water moulds: include the downy mildews and Phytophthora; neither produce structures such as these. They both generally produce a downy growth on the underside of the leaf (in the case of Phytophthora with a lot of necrosis (browning)). Viruses: never produce structures that can be seen and they very rarely produce leaf spots. Leaf spots caused by viruses are usually in the form of rings.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362718.question: Abutilon and powdery leaves. Whats happening?
362718.explanation: The correct answer is Healthy. Its not a rust, simply pollen scattered over an adjacent leaf. Sometimes the most obvious answer is the correct one. Dont over-complicate diagnoses. Flower production is big, big business in Colombia and growers are always on the look out for imperfections. This isnt one.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

346543.question: The symptoms are due to mites attacking grapevine. How can you tell that this is not downy mildew causing these symptoms?
options: The lumpy distortion is not typical of downy mildew infection
The pale growth on the underside of the leaf is never white in downy mildew infection
There is no downy mildew that attacks grapevine
The patchy distribution is not typical of downy mildew infection
I dont know and I dont want to guess
346543.correct_answer: The lumpy distortion is not typical of downy mildew infection
346543.explanation: The correct answer is: The lumpy distortion is not typical of downy mildew infection. This pest and pathogen are often confused, but downy mildews will rarely cause leaf distortion and this lumpy distortion (rugosity) is typical of mite infestation. The incorrect answers were: The pale growth on the underside of the leaf is never white in downy mildew infection. The sporulation on the underside of leaves infected with downy mildew can be white, grey, pink or purple. There is no downy mildew that attacks grapevine. This is not true and Grapevine downy mildew ( Plasmopara viticola) is a major problem for the wine industry. The patchy distribution is not typical of downy mildew infection. The distribution on these leaves is very typical of downy mildew infection.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355514.question: When assessing symptoms on a diseased plant, which stage of disease development is it best to study?
options: Dead material where the symptoms have been fully expressed
Asymptomatic tissue  after infection but before symptoms appear
Recently infected material where the symptoms are still developing
Material that is almost dead but not quite
I dont know and dont want to guess
355514.correct_answer: Recently infected material where the symptoms are still developing
355514.explanation: The correct answer is: Recently infected material, where the symptoms are still developing: This is where the pathogen will be most active and the symptoms not modified by other microbes moving in on the dead tissue . The incorrect answers were: Dead material, where the symptoms have been fully expressed; it is difficult to work out why a leaf or plant has died as they often look the same (black and shrivelled). Asymptomatic tissue : after infection but before symptoms appear; if there are no symptoms (even if there is infection) it is not possible to do a field diagnosis . Material that is almost dead but not quite; the amount of saprobes that will be colonising the tissue will make for confusing symptoms.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355520.question: Brown and green aphids.  What is the relationship between them?
options: Brown are males green are females
Brown are parasitized green are healthy
The brown insects are not aphids and are predators of the aphids
I dont know and I dont want to guess
355520.correct_answer: Brown are parasitized green are healthy
355520.explanation: The correct answer is: Brown are parasitized; green are healthy: The brown aphids are empty shells, the parasitoid has eaten the interior and has emerged. The green aphids are currently healthy. The incorrect answers were: Brown are males; green are females ; brown male aphids do exist, but almost all aphids are female. Two different species of aphid; no, they are all the same species. The brown insects are not aphids and are predators of the aphids; no, they are all (or were all) aphids.

363134.question: This is the systemic phase of downy mildew of pea. However, if you were unfamiliar with this symptom what would a reasonable diagnosis be?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363134.explanation: The correct answer is: This weird growth could easily be mistaken for herbicide damage. The pathogen has entered the meristem and produces this waxy weird growth.  Overnight incubation in a plastic bag will induce the more familiar downy sporulation.

364190.question: Which of these is a reporting tool for tree pathogens and pests in Great Britain?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
364190.explanation: The correct answer is: TreeAlert Developed by the Forestry Commission, Tree Alert is an online reporting tool for forestry professionals and those with knowledge of trees and woods. Information about trees showing symptoms of pests or diseases can be recorded and submitted for further verification. https://treealert.forestresearch.gov.uk/ If you would like to find out more about the diseases mentioned in the quiz please visit the Forest Research webpage. https://www.forestresearch.gov.uk/tools-and-resources/fthr/pest-and-disease-resources/ Another valuable resource is the Observatree website where there are dedicated pages for pest and diseases. https://www.observatree.org.uk/

351964.question: The symptoms of lettuce big vein virus; how would a diagnostic laboratory make a definitive diagnosis?
options: Squash a small amount of tissue  mount this with a cover slip and observe under a highpower microscope
Attempt to grow the virus on specialist agar from a small amount of leaf which has been briefly dipped in dilute bleach
Using molecular protocols extract infected plant tissue and amplify the nucleic acids for analysis
Isolate the virus particles from the vector
I dont know and dont want to guess
351964.correct_answer: Using molecular protocols extract infected plant tissue and amplify the nucleic acids for analysis
351964.explanation: The correct answer is: Using molecular experimental protocols, extract infected plant tissue and amplify the nucleic acids for analysis. To amplify up the nucleic acid (usually RNA but may be DNA ) and analyse this is the way in which most laboratories now identify plant viruses. The incorrect answers were: Squash a small amount of tissue , mount this with a cover slip and observe under a high-power microscope; this would be true for fungal pathogens, but viruses are too small to be seen with a light microscope. Attempt to grow the virus on specialist agar from a small amount of leaf which has been briefly dipped in dilute bleach; this would be true for many fungal and bacterial pathogens, but viruses dont grow on agar. Isolate the virus particles from the vector ; it may be possible to isolate the virus from the vector , but the virus particles will still be too small to be seen.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355517.question: These are fungal fruiting bodies growing on the host leaf. Clearly, a fungal pathogen is responsible, but what does it mean if there are no fungal fruiting bodies within the infected area?
options: The cause is not a fungal pathogen
The cause is either bacterial or viral
It is an abiotic problem of some sort
The cause could be a fungal pathogen
I dont know and I dont want to guess
355517.correct_answer: The cause could be a fungal pathogen
355517.explanation: The correct answer is: The cause could be a fungal pathogen : The presence of small black dots embedded within the host (and cannot be wiped off) is a clear indication that the cause is a coelomycete ( ascomycete ), however there are many fungi  hyphomycetes (also ascomycete )  that do not produce such structures. The incorrect answers were: The cause is not a fungal pathogen ; you could not conclude this based on absence of fruiting bodies. The cause is either bacterial or viral; you could not conclude this based on absence of fruiting bodies. An abiotic problem of some sort; you could not conclude this based on absence of fruiting bodies.

355777.question: Outgrowth on wild rose. What is the cause?
355777.explanation: The correct answer is: Insect damage: Diplolepis rosae , a wasp. It appears to have several common names: rose Bedegaur gall ; Robins pincushion Comments on the other options: Crown gall occurs on stems, not on leaves, and this is a fleshy rather than woody growth. Herbicides can interrupt normal growth, but the symptoms would occur over a wider area of the plant (see q1).

363135.question: This is downy mildew of basil.  The symptoms are unusual for a downy mildew.  What are these symptoms more typical of?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363135.explanation: The correct answer is: The downy mildews are closely related to Phytophthora and in this case the dark necrosis is more typical of Phytophthora infection. Downy mildews often have a biotrophic phase which does not trigger the host defences. It appears that in the case of basil downy mildew this phase is very short!

356996.question: The soft downy growth on the underside of leaves with light mottling on the upper surface is typical of downy mildews but this is not a downy mildew pathogen. Based on first principles what would predict the cause to be?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
356996.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungi: Although the symptoms look like those of a downy mildew this is a fungal pathogen ( Passalora fulva ).  None of the other alternatives ever produce additional growth on a plant.

362031.question: Why are these potato shoots dead? Perhaps its a disease, or maybe not ...
362031.explanation: The correct answer is: Abiotic Comments: A severe frost damaged these tender potato shoots. Note that all died suddenly at the same time, suggesting a massive change. In this case, its unseasonably cold temperatures overnight (in Bolivia).

357006.question: This is the most well known of all the exceptions to the rules. This is blossom end rot caused by erratic watering leading to a localised calcium shortage at the distal end of the fruit.   However what pathogen or pest would typically cause these symptoms?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357006.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacteria: Without prior knowledge of this complaint it would be a reasonable to suggest that the cause was a bacterial (or fungal) pathogen . Viruses and insects do not generally cause tissue death as seen here and nematodes will only rarely attack above ground.

357690.question: Seen in routine testing of seed potatoes (those sold for next seasons planting).
357690.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial ring rot , caused by Clavibacter michiganensis subsp. sepedonicus Comments : Above ground symptoms include vascular staining and wilt . There are several causes of wilting in potato. Internal examination of tubers is helpful in distinguishing the likely cause.

362717.question: Can you suggest why all the peach leaves are curling?
362717.explanation: The correct answer is Confused. No idea, but unlikely to be biotic given the uniform curling in all the leaves. Diseases (and pests) are progressive, so you see different stages of symptom development and in different parts of the plant.

362034.question: A rowan tree in steep decline. Note the damage to the trunk. Is this physical damage or some type of pest or pathogen (i.e. biotic)?
362034.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Time for a confession: this was in my parents garden and I was confused for many years until a chance comment by a colleague: rowan is a host for fireblight, a bacterial disease . Perhaps more often seen on hawthorn in natural settings and of course a big problem on apple and other fruit trees in the Rose family.

346540.question: What aspect of these leafspots indicate they are due to fungal infections?
options: Circular and they are not spreading from the edge of the leaf
They are not spreading from the edge of the leaf
Dont know and dont want to guess
346540.explanation: The correct answer is: All of the above All the features of these leaf spots indicate they are caused by a fungus: a clearly defined border of the spot ; not spreading along veins; no visible limitation of spread by veins; they are not associated with the edge of the leaf or with damage; but most telling of all, is that you can see the fungus as rings of small raised black lumps within the spots. The incorrect answers were: Strong clearly defined border see above. Circular and they are not spreading from the edge of the leaf see above. They are not spreading from the edge of the leaf see above.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352371.question: Botanical extracts are sometimes used as local remedies to control pests and diseases.  How should these control measures be classified?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
352371.explanation: The correct answer is: Chemical. This may seem a surprise, but an extract from a plant contains chemicals that will control the pests and diseases.  The origin of the chemical (in this case a plant) does not alter the fact that chemicals are being used to control the problem. The incorrect answers were: Biological; no, even though the chemical is from a biological source, it is not biological control . Cultural ; it may be part of the local culture, but this is not how the word cultural control is used. Organic; there are very strict rules with regard to what can be sprayed onto crop plants when in an organic regime.   Just because the chemical is from a natural source does not make it approved for organic use.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364185.question: Cryphonectria parasitica is a significant pathogen on sweet chestnuts. What are the most common symptoms of this pathogen?
options: Masses of pinhead sized yelloworange to reddishbrown pustules
364185.explanation: The correct answer is: All of the above Conspicuous and often numerous sunken, bright orange-brown cankers can occur on the bark of young branches of infected trees. The cankers caused by chestnut blight can eventually girdle branches and stems, with all live tissue above the canker dying. On grafted trees, infections are most frequently found in areas close to the graft where callusing occurs, whereas in orchard and coppiced trees infections usually occur at the base of the stem (collars or insertion points). Masses of pin-head sized, yellow-orange to reddish-brown pustules may also be evident on infected bark. These fruiting bodies erupt through lenticels (gas exchange structures) in the bark and exude long, yellow-orange tendrils/threads of spores in humid and wet weather. Another obvious symptom of this disease is wilted and brown dying and dead leaves which are retained by the tree above a girdling canker . Below the canker , epicormic growth (prolific sprouting) may be visible.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

354524.question: Sycamore trees growing on steep slope behind the beach in Scarborough. Why are the leaves dying?
354524.explanation: The correct answer is: Squirrel damage. They strip the bark to feed on the sweet sap below. Once the stem is ringed the leaves above die quickly. Frequently seen in some years on isolated or small groups of trees. Comments on the other options: The large area with dying leaves suggests that a major branch has been damaged below. Wilt pathogens result in a more uneven pattern of leaf death; and I dont know of any such pathogens affecting sycamore, or Acer species in the UK. The tree was too far from the sea to be affected by salt damage, and the pattern of damage would have been less severe and more diffuse.

355518.question: These are the symptoms of bacterial speck on tomato.  This disease breaks many of the rules associated with the diagnosis of a bacterial disease.
options: Small lesions of limited size not associated with damage
No fruiting bodies associated with the spots
I dont know and dont want to guess
355518.correct_answer: Small lesions of limited size not associated with damage
355518.explanation: The correct answer is: Small lesions of limited size, not associated with damage: Typically, bacterial infections are associated with leaf damage or the edge of the leaf.  In wet weather, they spread aggressively across the leaf.  These symptoms are not seen here, but are typical of this pathogen . The incorrect answers were: No fruiting bodies associated with the spots; there are never structures of any sort associated with bacterial infection. The plant is not wilting; bacterial stem infections frequently give rise to wilt , but leaf infection does not. Mosaic is not present; a mosaic is typical of viral diseases and not associated with bacterial infection.

363137.question: This is downy mildew of maize. Again the symptoms are not typical of a downy mildew what would be a reasonable diagnosis if you were unfamiliar with this disease?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363137.explanation: The correct answer is: These downy mildew symptoms could be mistaken for viral infection: The yellowing of the leaves with the green streaks do look very much like viral symptoms.  The yellowing is also typical of nutrient deficiency but note none of the nearby plants have the same symptom .

354527.question: These grapefruit trees in Cyprus looked fine when viewed from higher up a hillside, but in fact had massive gum production on their trunks. What is going on here?
options: Harvesting damage when cutting with knives
354527.explanation: The correct answer is: Physiological stress (I think). The staining around the exit of this spectacular oozing might suggest something pathological, yet on balance I think this is abiotic . The crowns were healthy and the trees productive, giving further weight to my rapid field diagnosis (I was on holiday). Comments on the other options: Fungal gummosis is common on citrus species and is associated with Phytophthora species (I know, its not a fungus  but no one calls this Oomycete or Fungus-like gummosis ). The gummosis is lower down on the trunk and accompanied by heavy staining below and dieback and decline in the crown. Gummosis is a common symptom in trees and though pathogens are involved its often a sign of physiological disturbance.
