363760.question: The dwarfing of these poinsettias is due to a phytoplasma infection. Phytoplasmas are bacteria like organisms that are vectored by insects.   Where can Phytoplasmas replicate?
options: In a host plant or an insect vector
I dont know and I dont want to guess
363760.correct_answer: In a host plant or an insect vector
363760.explanation: The correct answer is: In the host plant and the insect vector : Phytoplasmas are vectored in a similar way to plant viruses but generally have a much more intimate relationship with the vector and usually replicate in both hosts.  Unlike mycoplasmas phytoplasmas cannot be cultured.

363142.question: Downy mildew of lettuce.  This photo provides a general view of the symptoms but what would be your first diagnosis based on this photo ?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363142.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial infection. The advanced stage of the downy mildew infection has caused yellowing and necrosis . Many things could do this but for me it looks superficially like a bacterial infection.

357688.question: Above ground, leaves are wilting on this broad bean plant in Bolivia. The cut lower stem and root is shown in the photo. What is the cause?.
357688.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal rot (possibly Fusarium) Comments : The dark inner staining of the root suggests either a fungus or bacterial infection. I dont know of any bacterial wilt on broad beans  bacterial blight , yes, but there were no lesions on the leaves.

361419.question: What is causing these lesions on this asparagus stem?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
361419.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection: These lesions are due to Cercospora leaf spot caused by Cercospora asparagi. Symptoms are small, oval, grey to tan lesions with reddish brown borders on the needles and small branches. Spores of the fungus are produced on the lesions and are dispersed by wind and rain.

344551.question: This larva is cabbage stem flea beetle.  It is not possible to see the larva in great detail here, but what would it look like if examined in detail?
options: Welldeveloped head capsule and multiple prolegs short stubby legs on the abdomen
No head capsule and multiple prolegs short stubby legs on the abdomen
No head capsule and no prolegs short stubby legs on the abdomen
Welldeveloped head capsule and no prolegs short stubby legs on the abdomen
I dont know and dont want to guess
344551.correct_answer: Welldeveloped head capsule and no prolegs short stubby legs on the abdomen
344551.explanation: The correct answer is: Well-developed head capsule and no prolegs (short stubby legs on the abdomen) The larvae of beetles are grubs. They have a large head, no prolegs but often have well developed thoracic legs (true legs). However, in borers and stem dwellers, these may be extremely small. The incorrect answers were: Well-developed head capsule and multiple prolegs (short stubby legs on the abdomen) This morphology is typical of a moth larva; a caterpillar. No head capsule and multiple prolegs (short stubby legs on the abdomen) This morphology is typical of a fly larva; a maggot (the prolegs may be very small) No head capsule and no prolegs (short stubby legs on the abdomen) This morphology is typical of a fly larva; a maggot.

options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363141.explanation: The correct answer is: The lightly mottled regions appear similar to the feeding of mites. The fluffy growth on the underside of the leaf left no doubt as to true cause.

363139.question: This is crazy top of maize caused by a downy mildew.  What would these symptoms more typically be associated with?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
363139.explanation: The correct answer is: Crazy top is an apt name and does look rather like herbicide damage In a similar way to the systemic phase in peas the pathogen has clearly entered the meristem which results in this disorganised growth habit.

366404.question: Post-border  surveillance Q2 Inspectors conduct surveys at a range of sites, including propagators, nurseries, distribution centres, wholesalers, landscapers, aquatic plant retailers, vineyards, community orchards, heritage gardens, managed parks and gardens. The number of visits depends on the potential to facilitate the spread of diseases further through the supply chain.  Businesses are rated as either low, medium, high, or very high. Choose the medium risk site from below:
options: A small independent that operates in spring growing bedding plants from seed
A nursery that imports cuttings from nonEU countries for growing on and sells these plants to garden centres
A wholesaler that buys plants from the EU and sells plants to supermarkets
I dont know and I dont want to guess
366404.correct_answer: A nursery that imports cuttings from nonEU countries for growing on and sells these plants to garden centres
366404.explanation: Correct answer : A nursery that imports cuttings from non-EU countries for growing on and sells these plants to garden centres. Low risks sites trade in UK origin plants and sell to the end user (e.g. garden centre customers). High risk sites buy in from third country outside of the EU, propagate plants (as opposed to growing them on), and sell plants on to other distributers. Surveys are not undertaken randomly, they are done on a risk-related basis taking account of business activity, hosts traded, origin of plants, volume and trade and level of distribution.

363383.question: What is the cause of this browning on this potato leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
363383.explanation: The correct answer is: Mite feeding. The iron rust mite Polyphagotarsonemus latus feeding on potato causes what looks like iron rust.  The mites are too small to be seen as they are broad mites. It is a problem in the tropics and in temperate regions in glasshouses.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

351960.question: This brinjal/eggplant/aubergine is suffering from Verticillium wilt. Which pathogen/pest group could these symptoms be realistically mistaken for?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
351960.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial leaf spotting: What appear to be infection points spreading from the leaf edges could easily be mistaken for bacterial infection. The incorrect answers were: Viral infection; viruses rarely cause localised symptoms such as this and the symptoms are usually leaf distortion and mosaic . Nematode infection; the most common symptom of nematode infection is usually a wilt , only later do the leaves begin to show other symptoms generally caused by the stress of the wilting. Mite damage; the speckling that is usually the first sign of mite infestation may start in localised patches but will spread before those patches become very severe.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

354530.question: Lime is a popular roadside tree in many European countries. This example was photographed in Budapest. Why are the edges of the leaf drying up and going brown?
options: Leaf burn caused by high temperatures
354530.explanation: The correct answer is: Salt damage. Winters are cold and icy, hence the liberal application of salt on the roads. Comments on the other options: Initially confused by the uniform development of symptoms, Dr Phil suggested that salt had been translocated to the leaves, where high concentrations had resulted in this browning. Pests and diseases would produce more varied and scattered symptoms, with evidence of feeding damage, necrosis and so on. High temperatures for prolonged periods are more likely to induce leaf curling prior to death.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

344549.question: The symptoms seen here are that of yellow rust caused by Puccinia striiformis f.sp. tritici on wheat. It has relatively recently been shown to be macrocyclic and the alternative host is Barberry.  What will the yellow (Urediniospore) spores seen in the photo infect?
options: I dont know and dont want to guess
344549.explanation: The correct answer is: Only wheat Urediniospores will always infect the host plant on which they were produced. It is the teliospores, which will give rise to the basidiospores, that will ultimately infect the barberry. From a crop protection point of view, a farmer needs to prevent the urediniospores re-infecting the wheat. The incorrect answers were: Wheat and barberry See above Only barberry See above Technically neither wheat nor barberry See above

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

344547.question: Potatoes are prone to viral infections (as seen here) partially because they are vegetatively propagated. In other crops, to what extent are viruses passed into seed?
options: All viruses are passed on at a low rate in the seed but the industry lives with this
Some viruses are always passed on through seed as it is the only means of spread
The level of transmission into seed can be significant in some cases but the proportion of infected seed varies by crop and virus
The process of seed production will remove all viruses and what appears to be seed infection is actually contamination from seed coat
I dont know and dont want to guess
344547.correct_answer: The level of transmission into seed can be significant in some cases but the proportion of infected seed varies by crop and virus
344547.explanation: The correct answer is: The level of transmission into seed can be significant in some cases, but the proportion of infected seed varies by crop and virus . A few viruses will be carried over into the seed of the plant in a few cases. The percentage of infected seed varies depending on the crop and virus .  (Pea seed-borne mosaic virus is a good example). The incorrect answers were: All viruses are passed on at a low rate in the seed, but the industry lives with this. No. Some viruses may be passed on into seed, but this is relatively unusual. Some viruses are always passed on through seed as it is the only means of spread This is not the case and all viruses have some other means of infecting plants The process of seed production will remove all viruses and what appears to be seed infection is actually contamination from seed coat. Contamination of the seed coat does occur in some cases (e.g. TMV on tomatoes) but not many viruses can survive outside the host.  If the seed is contaminated, the virus particles can be literally washed off with bleach.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

350671.question: What is causing the yellow regions on these clover leaves?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
350671.explanation: The correct answer is: Genetic disturbance. The yellow regions are distributed as zones. This strongly indicates a genetic issue within the leaf. The incorrect answers were: Lack of nutrient: symptoms of nutrient deficiency can affect regions of the leaf (veins, edges etc) but would not show up in zones of the leaf such as this. Viral infection: the blocks of yellow are not typical of viral infection, it is often more of a pattern of yellow and green across the entire leaf; a mosaic . Herbicide spray damage : yellowing is a common symptom of herbicide damage but the clear lines of yellow and green could not be due to the effects of herbicide .

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355778.question: Maize cob with black swellings. What is the cause?
355778.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungus. This is maize smut ( Ustilago maydis ). Smuts infect floral parts and produce black powdery masses, and, in this case, considerable swelling. Smutty cobs are edible and much liked in Mexico. Ive eaten them. Comments on the other options: The powdery masses are a bit of a fungus give away. Excess nitrogen wouldnt result in swelling. Early frost would kill tissue , not cause new growth. There are phytoplasmas on maize which interfere with general growth e.g. maize reddening and corn stunt.

361087.question: Phytophthora infestans famously caused the great famine in Ireland, in 1845. Potatoes had been grown in Ireland for at least 200 years before that, but when was late blight first seen in Ireland?
options: Since they were first grown in Ireland
I dont know and I dont want to guess
361087.explanation: The correct answer is: 1845. Until 1845, Phytophthora infestans was unknown in Ireland, it was accidentally introduced at this time and immediately caused a huge famine.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

358236.question: What are these small swellings on the side of these soybean roots?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
358236.explanation: The correct answer is: Nematode cysts: Cysts are much smaller than nodules or galls. The cyst is the dead body of the female nematode and remains firmly attached to the root.  These cysts are full of (200-400) nematode eggs and will survive for years in the soil, ready to infect another susceptible crop.

364667.question: When is it important to blend fungicide products in the spray tank?
options: If the product being used contains only one active ingredient
If the product used is already mixture of active ingredients
If the pathogen is below ground
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364667.correct_answer: If the product being used contains only one active ingredient
364667.explanation: The correct answer is: If the product being used contains only one active ingredient. If the commercial product purchased from the ag chem store contains only one active ingredient it is important to mix the fungicide with another product.  Repeated use of a single active ingredient will lead to resistance .

366392.question: Pre-border  intelligence Q4 The main pathway by which pests enter England and Wales is in association with living plants and plant products.  To minimise the risk of pests being introduced, restrictions and requirements apply to the import of such material.  Material presents a different risk level depending on the country of origin and how it arrived in the country. Which of these is potentially the highest risk pathway?
options: Buying a cactus from an independent specialist grower
Buying Pelargonium bedding from multiple retailer BQ The Range Homebase Lidl IKEA who buys plants from EU and nonEU countries
Bringing Orchid cuttings back from Asia in rucksack no declaration
Buying an Olea europaea direct from the EU
Dont know and dont want to guess
366392.correct_answer: Bringing Orchid cuttings back from Asia in rucksack no declaration
366392.explanation: Correct answer : Bringing Orchid cuttings back from Asia in rucksack (no declaration) All plant movements pose a risk, but the greatest would be the orchids in a rucksack. With the other options there is a degree of inspection / regulation. Plants for planting pose significant phytosanitary risk to the recipient country as they may be present for several years and will usually be planted in the wider environment. Further information https://www.gov.uk/government/news/public-urged-not-to-bring-plant-pests-and-disease-into-the-uk

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

355785.question: Why this dramatic difference in growth, compared to the surrounding plants? Seen in South Africa
355785.explanation: The correct answer is: Uneven application of cow manure. The farmer had been encouraged to add the manure by local extension officers, without them realising that supply was limited. Comments on the other options: The plants in this small patch are growing normally. There are no obvious symptoms  marks on the leaf, changes in colour, dying leaves and so on. Theres no sign of irrigation pipes. Different seed varieties would show less marked growth differences and mature plants would not occur in a distinct patch . And no, its not a phytoplasma .

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

361416.question: What has caused the lesion on this asparagus stem?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
361416.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection: The strong border indicates a fungal infection but the fruiting bodies within the lesion put it beyond doubt. This infection is caused by Phaeosphaeria spp.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

348216.question: 'Bacterial streaming test' is a good technique to diagnose bacterial wilt diseases.  The cut stem is hung in a glass of water and the cut-end viewed. What time scale is required to see the effect?
options: Viewed very quickly a few seconds and you will have missed it
Overnight is best as this allows the bacteria to really flood out
I dont know and I dont want to guess
348216.explanation: The correct answer is: About 3  10 minutes should be enough. When the water is extremely still and viewed against a black background, fine wisps of milky fluid can be seen emerging from the cut end of the stem.  It is sometimes easier to take a photo and view the photo than to see it with your eye. The incorrect answers were: Viewed very quickly; a few seconds and you will have missed it. This is too short. You need to allow time for the bacteria to begin to flow. Overnight is best as this allows the bacteria to really flood out. The bacteria will have exited the stem by this time and you will not see them in the water. 3  4 hours is about right. This is too long. The bacteria will have exited the stem by this time and you will not see them in the water.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357691.question: Damage seen inside the base (corm) of a banana, and linked to above ground collapse of plant and general decline. What is happening?
357691.explanation: The correct answer is: Banana weevil ( Cosmopolites sordidus ) Comments : There are many reasons why bananas decline, and the only way to identify the most likely cause is by looking inside the pseudostem and low down for tell-tale signs .- in this case the black pockets associated with weevil damage. Look closely and you can see the larva top left. Also known as the banana borer.

357683.question: Potatoes in Syria often show reduced and weak growth but no obvious above-ground symptoms. The photo shows what is happening in the soil. What does this suggest as a likely cause?
357683.explanation: The correct answer is: Orobanche, parasitic plant. Note the distinct purple shoots coming from the potato tuber. Comments : Orobanche, or broomrape, is a genus with many species infecting a wide range of plants. Its a widespread cause of significant losses in potatoes.

363375.question: Not a plant path question but important for potato production. Which of these two insects (or both) are pests of potato?
options: The one with tan coloured antennae
The one with black coloured antennae
363375.correct_answer: The one with black coloured antennae
363375.explanation: The correct answer is: The one with black coloured antennae. This is the famous Colorado beetle Leptinotarsa decemlineata an innocuous insect which only became a serious pest of potato when the potato was introduced to its native range.  The beetle with the tan antennae is the sunflower beetle Zygogramma exclamationis

365346.question: The holes in this almond leaf look very much like insect feeding but that is not the case.  What has caused the development of these symptoms?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365346.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal infection This is shot hole disease commonly seen on Prunus species. It  is caused by Stigmina fungus ( Wilsonomyces carpophilus ).  The infection elicits such an extreme reaction by the host that the infected area drops from the leaf leaving the characteristic (if you know) hole.

358230.question: This is a very common pathogen on wheat.  Healthy plants on left, diseased on right. The roots are characteristically black and plants stunted. What is the cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
358230.explanation: The correct answer is: Take all This disease caused by Gaeumannomyces graminis var. graminis produces indistinct symptoms above ground; stunting and yellowing.  The stubby black roots are characteristic.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362993.question: Courgette growing at RHS Wisley
362993.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: Looks like another virus to me. Not sure which one. Causing little or no obvious damage. By the way, I suspect Im in a minority in looking for plant health problems as I walk round Wisley (which is close to where I live).

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

352367.question: When applying a crop protection chemical, a mask is essential. What does a poor-quality mask (left) achieve?
options: Provides limited protection to the operator
Reminds the operator that the chemical is potentially hazardous
Provides the operator with a false sense of security
Has no effect on the behaviour of the operator or their exposure
Dont know and dont want to guess
352367.correct_answer: Provides the operator with a false sense of security
352367.explanation: The correct answer is: Provides the operator with a false sense of security: Unless the PPE is actually fit for purpose, it may provide the illusion of protection to the operator so they will believe they are protected and change their behaviour and ultimately become more exposed. The incorrect answers were: Provides limited protection to the operator; there may be very limited protection offered but this is often tiny compared to the extent the operators believe they are protected. It is my personal opinion that these masks that offer almost no protection should be banned. Reminds the operator that the chemical is potentially hazardous; this could be the case but it also reminds the operator that they think they are protected when they are not. Has no effect on the behaviour of the operator or their exposure; providing a mask will alter the behaviour of the operator exposing themselves to greater hazard.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

359218.question: What is causing this rot at the base of this lettuce?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
359218.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungus Not many fungi cause such total tissue collapse as seen here, but this is a Sclerotinia rot . The presence of the hyphae indicates that it is not a bacterial pathogen and the presence of black cannon-ball sclerotia (fungal resting spores) indicate it has to be a fungal pathogen .   Bacteria never produce structures large enough to be seen and Phytophthora (a very unusual pathogen on lettuce) would not produce the sclerotia.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

354528.question: Holm oak is an evergreen species. These symptoms were seen in May on a tree growing next to a popular walking route. What has caused these symptoms?
options: Frost damage from earlier in the year
354528.explanation: The correct answer is: Leaf miner. The holm oaks around where in live in SW London are plastered with infestations. Doesnt seem to affect the growth and health of the trees, There are two species found on holm oak. This appears to be Phyllonorycter messaniella , the leaf blotch leafminer. Comments on the other options: These are superficial symptoms caused by caterpillars feeding beneath the leaf epidermis . A fungal leaf spot would kill the part of the leaf affected and, typically, have a more defined shape. This evergreen oak has evolved to keep its leaves over winter and though low temperatures could kill off young growth in early spring, for example, it wouldnt produce these blotches. Nor would a virus .

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364181.question: In 2012 this fungus was first identified causing wilting of foliage, canopy dieback, diamond-shaped lesions on ash trees in the UK.  What is this fungus?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
364181.explanation: The correct answer is: Hymenoscyphus fraxineus Ash dieback is a highly destructive disease of ash trees ( Fraxinus species), especially the United Kingdoms native ash species, common ash ( Fraxinus excelsior ). It is caused by a fungus named Hymenoscyphus fraxineus ( H. fraxineus ), which is of eastern Asian origin. The disease is also known as Chalara, ash dieback , and Chalara dieback of ash. Calling it Chalara ash dieback helps to distinguish it from dieback on ash trees caused by other agents.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357323.question: What is the material on the lower side of this laurel leaf?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
357323.explanation: The correct answer is: Powdery mildew caused by either Podosphaera tridactyla or Podosphaera pannosa . Unusually, the growth is on the underside of the leaf. The developing fruiting bodies (cleistothecia) are clearly visible. The infection can become so severe that portions of the tissue fall out resembling insect damage.

365341.question: The symptom of wilting and leaf edge necrosis are typical of bacterial infection but that is not the case here,  what has caused these symptoms on this aubergine/egg plant?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
365341.explanation: The correct answer is: Verticillium wilt Verticillium albo-atrum causes a disease often referred to as Verticillium wilt  however a wilt is often not the first symptom and may be absent all together following infection.

metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

360087.question: What are these large black lumps of fungal material called?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360087.explanation: The correct answer is: Sclerotia Unlike the small black cleistothecia seen in the previous question, these are large 5-10mm hard black lumps.  They can be formed by many fungi but are most commonly seen in Sclerotinia infections.  The sclerotia are often surrounded by a mass of white hyphae as seen here.

metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

357987.question: This is an ornamental laurel leaf; how many pathogens are infecting the leaf?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
357987.explanation: The correct answer is: One pathogen : Powdery mildew on laurel can be extremely severe.  The infected area can drop out, giving the impression of insect feeding damage. The black dots among the white powdery growth are the cleistothecia, the sexual stage of the fungus.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

349790.question: Alternate host is a phrase often heard in plant pathology.  What does alternate host mean?
options: Any wild plant that is susceptible to a pathogen
A crop plant that is slightly susceptible to a pathogen  but the yield is not affected
A plant that the pathogen will survive on when the crop is not in production
An additional species of plant which is required for the pathogen to complete its full lifecycle
I dont know and I dont want to guess
349790.correct_answer: An additional species of plant which is required for the pathogen to complete its full lifecycle
349790.explanation: The correct answer is: An additional species of plant which is required for the pathogen to complete its full lifecycle: Some rust fungi have complicated life cycles. Whilst farmers are generally familiar with the asexual spore production on crop plants, they are less familiar with the sexual phase of the same fungus which often takes place on an unrelated plant. It is this other plant that is termed the alternate host . The incorrect answers were: Any wild plant that is susceptible to a pathogen : this is not considered an alternate host ; it is just part of the host range of the fungus. A crop plant that is slightly susceptible to a pathogen , but not as badly as another crop: this is not considered an alternate host ; it is just part of the host range of the fungus. A plant that the pathogen will survive on when the crop is not in production: it is often the case that the alternate host allows the fungus to over-winter when the crop is not in production, but that is not what makes it an alternate host .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

364428.question: Various levels of severity of Parsnip yellow fleck virus on parsnip. The aphid vector (Cavariella aegopodii) transmits PYFV in a semi-persistent manner but why is there no spread between plants within a crop of parsnips.
options: The aphid does not feed on parsnips
The virus requires a helper virus to be transmitted and this does not survive in parsnips
The symptoms are transient so it appears not to spread
Once infected the parsnip will produce chemicals that repel aphids
I dont know and I dont want to guess
364428.correct_answer: The virus requires a helper virus to be transmitted and this does not survive in parsnips
364428.explanation: Answer: The virus requires a helper virus to be transmitted and this does not survive in parsnips. The aphids feed on parsnips and the virus is present but it is never spread from one parsnip plant to another.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

344543.question: What does reddening in the leaves of crop plants indicate?
options: Definitely indicates a deficiency of phosphate
I dont know and dont want to guess
344543.explanation: The correct answer is: Generalised stress. Reddening (just as with yellowing) is often a sign of generalised stress. This may be due to a variety of factors, for example, abiotic pathogens and insect feeding.  Phosphate deficiency will often cause reddening of the lower leaves and can be diagnostic but that is not the only problem that induces this effect. The incorrect answers were: Definitely indicates a deficiency of phosphate This is a common symptom of P deficiency but is not the only cause of reddening. Insect larvae within the stem The stress caused by insect feeding will often cause reddening of the upper leaves but many other problems will do this too. Root problem of some sort Root problems may cause stress, leading to reddening, but that is not always the case.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

340688.question: This symptom is commonly seen in cassava growing regions. Notice that the necrotic (brown) areas are spreading from the leaf edges in each case. What is the most likely cause?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
340688.explanation: The correct answer is: Bacterial pathogen : This is bacterial blight of cassava. It is a well-known disease found in all areas where cassava is grown. It is caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. manihotis. The symptoms initially appear as water-soaked areas before the leaves turn brown and dry out.  The incorrect answers were: Fungal pathogens: can cause something similar, but do not start specifically at the leaf edge. Viral pathogens: almost never cause tissue death such as this; they generally produce leaf distortion and mosaics. Nematodes: can cause wilt and death of plants, but generally the whole plant will suffer and not just an isolated leaf or an area of a leaf.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

361415.question: What has caused this bunchy growth in these asparagus plants?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
361415.explanation: The correct answer is: Aphid attack: Very surprisingly (for me at least) these are the symptoms of the asparagus aphid Brachycorynella asparagi . It is extremely unusual for an aphid colony to cause this kind of alteration to the growth habit of a plant.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

363380.question: What is causing the problem here?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
363380.explanation: The correct answer is: Herbicide damage: Potatoes are difficult to kill with herbicides but these are the symptoms of low levels of Glyphosate on a potato volunteer.

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

362995.question: Onions growing at RHS Wisley
362995.explanation: The correct answer is: Biotic Comments: This is a rust, common on several onion relatives  the chives in my garden get it. Look out for rusty leeks bought from shops (though less common than it used to be).

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

342532.question: What is the relationship between the true fungi and the oomycetes (water moulds)?
options: The oomycetes are considered as the lower fungi
The two groups occupy different habitats and there is very little similarity between these groups
Superficially and genetically they are closely related but oomycetes are not technically fungi
Genetically the two groups are completely unrelated
Dont know and dont want to guess
342532.correct_answer: Genetically the two groups are completely unrelated
342532.explanation: The correct answer is: Genetically the two groups are completely unrelated. Despite the many similarities between these two groups (long filamentous hyphae and spore formation), it is now known that they are completely different organisms, with different biochemical structure and evolutionary lineages. IMAGE : Cucumber leaves attacked by a powdery mildew (fungus) left and a downy mildew ( oomycete ) right The incorrect answers were: The oomycetes are considered as the lower fungi; this would have been the correct answer 40 years ago but it has become clear that oomycetes are not fungi and are not related to fungi. The two groups occupy different habitats and there is very little similarity between these groups; the oomycetes and the fungi occupy very similar habitats and look very similar. Superficially and genetically, they are closely related but oomycetes are not technically fungi; they do appear superficially similar (and the oomycetes are often referred to as fungus-like organism) but they are not genetically related .

metadata.license: All rights reserved. Content © The British Society for Plant Pathology (BSPP)
metadata.author: BSPP - The British Society for Plant Pathology
metadata.title: The Big Plant Pathology Quiz

359639.question: A yule log is often a chocolate swiss roll but was a special log burnt at Christmas: it could have been many kinds of wood but was often oak or birch.  What type of pathogen is attacking this oak tree?
options: I dont know and I dont want to guess
359639.explanation: The correct answer is: Basidiomycete pathogen The only fungi that produce large fruiting structures such as toadstools, mushrooms, or (as in this case) brackets, are the Basidiomycetes.

362997.question: Cucurbit (squash/marrow) growing at RHS Wisley
362997.explanation: The correct answer is: Abiotic Comments: An older leaf loses its vigour. Note the classic indicator of lack of nutrients with the veins remaining green and the outer regions yellowing first.

362991.question: Maize growing in an open field in South Africa

351966.question: What could be causing the distortion on this maize leaf?
options: Crown gall caused by Agrobacterium tumefaciens
Dont know and dont want to guess
351966.explanation: The correct answer is: Smut fungus: This is leaf infection of maize by Ustilago maydis ( Mycosarcoma maydis ). Infection causing the black sooty spores on the cobs are a much more familiar sight. The incorrect answers were: Crown gall caused by Agrobacterium tumefaciens ; crown gall can produce galls of this size but the galls are never smooth they are usually brown and Agrobacterium does not infect grasses. Gall -forming insect; this is reasonable suggestion but (difficult to tell from the photo) the leaf is distorted and there are no galls there . Viral infection; the distortion seen here would not be so localised if it was caused by a virus .

352372.question: When a crop is harvested, the residue may be rich in predators and parasitoids (natural enemies) that will help to suppress any further outbreaks of the same pest. What should be done with the crop debris?
options: Burn it or compost it as far as is practical
Store the debris nearby to allow the natural enemies to emerge
Take it to a field where the same crop is being grown and spread it onto the soil
The decision as to what to do will depend on the crop and pest
I dont know and I dont want to guess
352372.correct_answer: The decision as to what to do will depend on the crop and pest
352372.explanation: The correct answer is: The decision as to what to do will depend on the crop and pest : Generally, it is appropriate to destroy the crop trash after harvest (ploughing or composting or burning), however there are times when it may be appropriate to remove it and store it.  If the pest is not mobile; the natural enemies are mobile and there is no threat from other pests or diseases, then this may be a sensible strategy. The incorrect answers were: Burn it or compost it as far as is practical; this is a safe option and is usually the correct one. Store the debris nearby to allow the natural enemies to emerge; this can be a good practice but should not be universally adopted unless you are aware of all the pests and diseases on the trash. Take it to a field where the same crop is being grown and spread it onto the soil; this is never appropriate and would completely undermine most of the benefits of crop rotation.

360089.question: A disease of chives with orange and black pustules.  The orange pustules are the uredinia spores, within the pustules, but what are the black regions?
options: Another spore type of the same fungus
A parasite of the fungus growing on the spores
Another disease unrelated to the orange pustules
Dont know and dont want to guess
360089.correct_answer: Another spore type of the same fungus
360089.explanation: The correct answer is: Another spore type of the same fungus: Rust fungi produce several types of spore .  The black regions are pustules of the same fungus: they are the teliospore phase of the disease .

360477.question: What is the white material on the leaf surface?
options: Dont know and dont want to guess
360477.explanation: The correct answer is: Spray residue: The leaves of these roses were sprayed with tetracycline, to prevent bacterial infection, and Thiophante methyl, to prevent fungal infection: the residue can clearly be seen.  Spraying crops with antibiotics is a practice which should be discouraged.

354531.question: An old ash tree growing by the main road. Why are the branches dying?
options: Repeated root damage by tractors in adjacent field  abiotic
Combination of fungal and abiotic dieback
354531.correct_answer: Combination of fungal and abiotic dieback
354531.explanation: The correct answer is: Fungal ( Hymenoscyphus fraxineus ) and abiotic dieback . Lets not forget that ash dieback of the abiotic variety has been around for decades in th UK. Separate the wispy dieback (fungal) around the crown periphery from the larger dead branches I associate with root disturbance and other abiotic factors. Described as stag-headed because they look like antlers. Comments on the other options: Air pollution is one of those fall-back options: when pest and disease options have been ostensibly eliminated look for something that could have a widespread impact on tree growth. Nutrient deficiencies is another fall-back option. Ive not included lightning damage. I said diagnosing tree health problems wasnt going to be easy ...
